name: Welder Additional Test Payment
rule_text: Any welder who is required to do additional testing by the Employer, shall be paid for weld time of four (4) hours per successful test
summary: A welder required to perform additional testing by the employer will be paid for 4 hours of weld time for each successful test.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_type (llm) == 'ADDITIONAL' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'SUCCESSFUL' -> ASSIGN(ST, 4)

expected_outcome.condition: 4 hours of ST for each successful 'additional' weld test.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule that grants a specific number of paid hours (entitlement) upon meeting certain criteria (successful test of a specific type). It's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it results in paid hours on a timesheet.

name: Welder Single Plate Test Payment
rule_text: (excluding the boiler ¼ Down Hand Plate or other single ¼ plate test, will be paid two (2) hours).
summary: As an exception to the standard 4-hour test payment, a welder will be paid 2 hours for a successful single 1/4 inch plate test.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_type (llm) == 'SINGLE_QUARTER_PLATE' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'SUCCESSFUL' -> ASSIGN(ST, 2) AND OVERRIDE('Welder Additional Test Payment')

expected_outcome.condition: 2 hours of ST for each successful single 1/4 inch plate test, overriding the 4-hour rule.

reasoning: This rule explicitly carves out an exception to a general rule, making it a classic exception_override. It changes the paid hour entitlement for a specific type of test.

name: Welder 3-Plate Test Maximum Payment
rule_text: Additional test consists of three plates welded in the vertical, horizontal and overhead positions and will be paid a maximum of four (4) hours total, upon successful completion.
summary: The 3-plate additional test (vertical, horizontal, overhead) is paid a maximum of 4 hours in total upon successful completion of all parts.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_type (llm) == '3_PLATE_ADDITIONAL' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'SUCCESSFUL' -> VALIDATE(total_payment <= 4_HOURS_ST)

expected_outcome.condition: Total payment for the 3-plate additional test must not exceed 4 hours.

reasoning: This rule establishes a maximum payment, which is a form of threshold or cap. It's condition_based because it applies only to a specific test type and outcome.

name: Welder Abbreviated Plate Test Payment
rule_text: Those requested to take an abbreviated version of the plate test will be compensated at one and a half (1.5) hours for each successful plate test.
summary: Welders will be paid 1.5 hours for each successful abbreviated plate test they are requested to take.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_type (llm) == 'ABBREVIATED_PLATE' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'SUCCESSFUL' -> ASSIGN(ST, 1.5)

expected_outcome.condition: 1.5 hours of ST for each successful abbreviated plate test.

reasoning: This is a straightforward condition_based rule that provides a specific payment (1.5 hours) for a defined activity (abbreviated test) with a required outcome (successful).

name: No Payment for Failed Weld Test
rule_text: In any event a welder will not be paid for a failed test.
summary: A welder will not be paid for any time related to a weld test that they fail.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'FAILED' -> ASSIGN(ST, 0) AND OVERRIDE('*Test_Payment_Rules')

expected_outcome.condition: No hours paid for a failed weld test, overriding any potential payment rules.

reasoning: This is a critical exception_override rule. The phrase 'In any event' signifies that it takes precedence over all other payment rules for tests, making it a high-priority rule that negates payment if the condition (failed test) is met.

name: Payment for Partial Success in Multi-Test Scenario
rule_text: If an Employer is requesting more than three (3) tests per welder and a welder has successfully completed three (3) of four (4) tests... he or she will be paid for the three (3) successful weld tests.
summary: If a welder is asked to take more than three tests and passes at least three, they will be paid for all the tests they successfully completed, regardless of whether they are ultimately retained by the employer.
depends_on: No Payment for Failed Weld Test
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_tests_requested (llm) > 3 AND welding_tests_successful (llm) >= 3 -> PAY(FOR_EACH_SUCCESSFUL_TEST)

expected_outcome.condition: Payment for each successful test is confirmed when at least 3 of 4+ tests are passed.

reasoning: This rule clarifies payment entitlement under a specific complex condition (partial success in a multi-test scenario). It's a condition_based rule that confirms the application of other payment rules.

name: Payment for Secondary Test (Actual Time)
rule_text: Should a secondary test be required by the Employer, the employee shall be paid for the time required to take such a test.
summary: If an employer requires an employee to take a secondary test, the employee must be paid for the actual time spent taking that test.
logical_representation: IF is_secondary_test_required (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(ST, actual_hours_on_test (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: Actual hours worked on a required secondary test are paid as ST.

reasoning: This rule differs from the flat-hour payments in 7.01. It creates an entitlement to be paid for actual time worked on a specific task, making it a condition_based rule under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Forfeiture of Test Pay for No-Show
rule_text: Any welder who successfully completes the welding test, but fails to report for work as notified, without a bona fide reason acceptable to the Employer, will not be eligible for any payment, including testing time and other allowances, as set out in Article 7.00.
summary: If a welder passes their test but then fails to show up for work as scheduled without a good reason, they forfeit all payments and allowances related to the testing process.
overrides: Travel Allowance for On-Site Weld Test
Travel & Subsistence for Out-of-Town Weld Test
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'SUCCESSFUL' AND reported_for_work (llm) == false -> ASSIGN(TOTAL_PAYMENT, 0) AND OVERRIDE('*Article_7_Payments_And_Allowances')

expected_outcome.condition: All test-related payments and allowances are forfeited if the welder passes but is a no-show for work.

reasoning: This is a powerful exception_override rule that negates multiple other entitlements based on the welder's post-test actions. It has a high execution order to ensure it is checked after other entitlements are calculated.

name: Alloy Welder Premium (Dispatched)
rule_text: Alloy welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of three dollars and twenty-five cents ($3.25) per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: A welder with a valid alloy certificate who was specifically dispatched as an alloy welder will receive an additional premium of $3.25 for every hour they work.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND has_valid_alloy_cert (llm) == true AND is_dispatched_as_alloy_welder (llm) == true -> ADD_PREMIUM(3.25_PER_HOUR_WORKED)

expected_outcome.condition: A $3.25/hr premium is paid to welders dispatched as alloy welders.

reasoning: This rule defines a specific monetary premium based on dispatch conditions and certification. It's a condition_based rule that directly impacts the billing rate for labor hours.

name: Reclassification to Alloy Welder On-Site
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to be certified by the Employer and is requested to perform alloy welding, the employee will be reclassified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium from the date of re-classification.
summary: If a regular welder on site has or gets an alloy certification and is asked to perform alloy welding, they will be reclassified as an alloy welder and start receiving the $3.25/hr premium from that day forward.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND is_dispatched_as_alloy_welder (llm) == false AND performs_alloy_welding (llm) == true AND has_valid_alloy_cert (llm) == true -> RECLASSIFY('ALLOY_WELDER') AND START_PREMIUM(FROM_RECLASSIFICATION_DATE)

expected_outcome.condition: A $3.25/hr premium begins for a non-dispatched welder from the date they are reclassified on site to perform alloy welding.

reasoning: This rule provides an alternative pathway to receiving the alloy premium, based on actions taken at the job site rather than at dispatch. It's a condition_based rule that alters an employee's classification and pay.

name: Alloy Welder Premium - No Pyramiding
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The $3.25/hr alloy welder premium is a flat addition for all hours worked and is not multiplied for overtime hours. It is included in the base rate for calculating vacation and holiday pay.
logical_representation: IF is_alloy_welder_premium_active (llm) == true -> VALIDATE(premium_calculation == 3.25 * daily_hours)

expected_outcome.condition: The total daily alloy premium amount must equal $3.25 times the total hours worked, not multiplied by OT/DT rates.

reasoning: This is a calculation rule that specifies how a premium interacts with overtime. It overrides standard pyramiding logic, where premiums might be multiplied by the OT rate, making it an exception_override.

name: 5x8 Standard Schedule Definition
rule_text: Eight (8) hours per day shall constitute a normal day of work. ... Forty (40) hours shall constitute a normal week's work, Monday through Friday inclusive.
summary: A standard work schedule is defined as 8 hours per day, 40 hours per week, from Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> DEFINE_SCHEDULE(daily_hours=8, weekly_hours=40)

expected_outcome.condition: The first 8 hours worked on a standard weekday (Mon-Fri) and the first 40 hours in a week are straight time.

reasoning: This rule establishes the fundamental definition of a standard 5x8 work week, which is a prerequisite for all other rules applying to this schedule. It is classified as schedule_definition.

name: 5x8 Standard Hours Window
rule_text: The normal hours of work shall be between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. for an eight (8) hour day
summary: For a standard 8-hour day, the normal work hours (straight time) are between 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> DEFINE_ST_WINDOW('07:00', '18:00')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked within the 7am to 6pm window on a standard 8-hour day are considered normal hours.

reasoning: This rule defines the time-of-day window for standard hours, which is a key part of the schedule definition. It follows the main schedule definition in execution order.

name: Penalty for Unilateral Shift Time Change
rule_text: If the foregoing starting or quitting times are changed without mutual agreement, applicable overtime rates shall be paid for any time worked before or after the above hours as a result of the change of times.
summary: If the employer changes the standard start/end times (7am-6pm window) without mutual agreement, any time worked outside that original window must be paid at overtime rates.
logical_representation: IF start_end_time_mutually_agreed (llm) == false AND (work_start_time (llm) < '07:00' OR work_end_time (llm) > '18:00') -> ASSIGN(OT, hours_outside_window)

expected_outcome.condition: When start/end times are changed without agreement, hours worked outside the 7am-6pm window are paid as OT.

reasoning: This rule is an exception that overrides the standard hours definition under the specific condition of a non-consensual schedule change. It's an override rule that modifies payment rates.

name: CWW Make-Up Day Pay Rule
rule_text: Work performed on a make-up day shall be paid at the regular straight time rate for the first ten (10) hours to a maximum of forty (40) hours per week, after which double time (2X) rates shall apply.
summary: On a compressed work week, an approved make-up day is paid at straight time for the first 10 hours, unless the weekly total exceeds 40 hours. All hours worked beyond either the 10-hour daily or 40-hour weekly limit are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_make_up_day (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(ST, UP_TO(10)) UNLESS weekly_hours > 40; IF daily_hours > 10 OR weekly_hours > 40 -> TRANSITION(DT)

expected_outcome.condition: On a make-up day, hours up to 10 daily and 40 weekly are ST. Any hours beyond either threshold are DT.

reasoning: This rule defines the specific pay thresholds for a conditional 'make-up day' within a compressed work week schedule. It's a threshold-based rule for a specific scenario.

name: CWW Make-Up Day Minimum Hours
rule_text: In no case shall the time scheduled on a make-up day be less than eight (8) hours except where weather conditions dictate otherwise.
summary: If a make-up day is worked on a compressed schedule, it must be scheduled for at least 8 hours, unless weather prevents it.
logical_representation: IF is_make_up_day (llm) == true -> VALIDATE(daily_hours >= 8)

expected_outcome.condition: A timesheet for a make-up day should show at least 8 hours of work.

reasoning: This is a conditional rule establishing a minimum work duration for a specific type of day (make-up day), used for validating the legitimacy of the day's timesheet entry.

name: CWW Weekly ST Threshold with Holiday
rule_text: Where a holiday occurs during the normal work week the maximum of thirty (30) hours per week shall form the basis of maximum straight time rate.
summary: On a compressed work week, if a statutory holiday occurs, the weekly straight time maximum is reduced from 40 to 30 hours before overtime rates apply.
logical_representation: IF week_contains_stat_holiday (llm) == true -> SET_THRESHOLD(weekly_ot_start, 30)

expected_outcome.condition: Weekly overtime begins after 30 hours in a week that includes a holiday.

reasoning: This rule is an exception that overrides the standard weekly overtime threshold when a specific condition (a holiday in the week) is met. It's a classic override rule.

name: Weekend and Holiday Pay
rule_text: Work performed on Saturday, Sunday, or Recognized Holidays shall be paid at the applicable overtime premium.
summary: All hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or a Recognized Holiday are paid at the applicable overtime premium, which is inferred to be double time (2X).
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday must be categorized as double time.

reasoning: This is a day-based rule that assigns a specific pay rate (double time) to all hours worked on certain types of days, overriding any standard weekday threshold logic.

name: Worked Lunch Break Penalty
rule_text: If this break falls outside the regular lunch break established on the job, they shall receive an additional allowance of one-half (½) hour of pay at straight time rates which shall be in addition to their regular straight time hours.
summary: If an employee works through their regular lunch break and their rescheduled break occurs outside the normal lunch period, they are entitled to an extra 0.5 hours of pay at straight time.
logical_representation: IF worked_during_lunch_break (llm) == true AND reassigned_lunch_outside_regular_break (llm) == true -> ADD_PAY(ST, 0.5)

expected_outcome.condition: An additional 0.5 ST hours should be present on the timesheet if the employee's reassigned lunch was outside the normal break time.

reasoning: This is a conditional rule that provides a specific monetary entitlement (as paid time) when an employee's break is disrupted and rescheduled inconveniently. It's a penalty payment.

name: 10-Hour Shift Paid Breaks Option
rule_text: When working ten (10) hour shifts, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two (2) breaks of one-half (½) hour each, both paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On a 10-hour shift, the employer can choose to provide two paid 30-minute breaks instead of the standard coffee breaks and unpaid lunch. This results in the employee being paid for the full 10 hours on site.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10_mon_thu', '4x10_tue_fri', '5x10'] AND paid_break_option_taken (llm) == true -> EXPECT(total_paid_hours == 10)

expected_outcome.condition: When this option is used for a 10-hour shift, the employee should be paid for 10 hours, with no deduction for a lunch break.

reasoning: This rule outlines a significant, employer-discretionary option that changes the calculation of total paid time by making the lunch break paid. It's a conditional override of standard unpaid lunch rules.

name: Work Week Start Definition
rule_text: For the purpose of clarification and to define Saturday and Sunday work, the work shall be deemed to commence at the starting time of the regular day shift on Monday morning.
summary: The work week officially begins at the start of the regular day shift on Monday morning. This definition is used to correctly identify Saturday and Sunday work.
logical_representation: DEFINE(work_week_start, 'MON', start_of_day_shift)

expected_outcome.condition: Establishes the anchor point for weekly calculations.

reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental starting point of the work week, which is a core concept for scheduling and weekly overtime calculations. Therefore, it is classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME and schedule_definition.

name: Flexible Shift Commencement
rule_text: Shifts may be commenced on any calendar day provided the appropriate requirements for shift premium and overtime as specified in this Agreement are met.
summary: Work shifts can start on any day of the week, including weekends, as long as the relevant shift premium and overtime pay rules are correctly applied.
logical_representation: ALLOW(shift_start_day, ANY) IF REQUIRE(shift_premium_rules_are_met) AND REQUIRE(overtime_rules_are_met)

expected_outcome.condition: Confirms that shifts starting on non-standard days are permissible if pay rules are followed.

reasoning: This rule sets a condition for when shifts can start, linking it to other pay rules. It's a condition that governs work timing, making it condition_based under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Shift Definitions and Timing
rule_text: For the purpose of defining the shifts, the 1st shift shall be the day shift which commences at 7:00 a.m. This starting time may be varied by mutual agreement to suit job requirements. The second (2nd) shift shall be the afternoon shift and shall follow the first (1st) shift. The third (3rd) shift shall be the night shift and shall follow the second (2nd) shift. Second (2nd) and third (3rd) shifts shall commence not later than one (1) hour after the completion of the preceding shift...
summary: Defines the three shifts: 1st (day, starts ~7:00 a.m.), 2nd (afternoon), and 3rd (night). The afternoon and night shifts must start no more than one hour after the previous shift ends.
logical_representation: DEFINE(shift_designation(llm), {'1st': 'DAY', '2nd': 'AFTERNOON', '3rd': 'NIGHT'}) AND REQUIRE(shift_2.start_time <= shift_1.end_time + 1_hour) AND REQUIRE(shift_3.start_time <= shift_2.end_time + 1_hour)

expected_outcome.condition: Validates that hours are correctly assigned to '1st', '2nd', or '3rd' shifts based on their start times and sequence.

reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the characteristics of the different shifts, which is a foundational element of scheduling. This fits the classification of LABOR_WORKED_TIME and rule type schedule_definition.

name: Shift Premium Entitlement
rule_text: A shift premium shall apply on all hours worked on second (2nd) and third (3rd) shifts at the rates as set out in the Wage and Benefit Schedule. All shift premium hours will be paid at a rate of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) per hour.
summary: A premium of $4.50 per hour must be paid for all hours worked during the second (afternoon) and third (night) shifts.
logical_representation: IF shift_designation (llm) IN ['2nd', '3rd'] THEN APPLY_PAYMENT(shift_premium_amount (llm): 4.50, unit: 'per_hour')

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked on a 2nd or 3rd shift.

reasoning: This rule establishes a specific monetary entitlement based on the condition of working a particular shift. This makes it condition_based. The topic is LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it's a direct payment for hours worked, even though it's not ST/OT/DT bucketing.

name: Overtime for Insufficient Rest Period
rule_text: When an employee is required to return to work without an eight (8) hour break, all work performed shall be paid for at the applicable overtime rates, until such time as the employee receives an eight (8) hour break.
summary: If an employee works a shift with less than an 8-hour rest break since their previous shift, all hours on the new shift must be paid at overtime rates. This overtime pay continues until the employee receives a full 8-hour break.
logical_representation: IF hours_since_last_shift (llm) < 8 THEN REASSIGN_BUCKET(ST, OT) FOR ALL hours UNTIL break_of_at_least_8_hours

expected_outcome.condition: For any hours that would normally be ST if the employee had less than an 8-hour break.

reasoning: This rule creates a special condition (less than 8-hour break) that overrides the normal straight-time pay rules, forcing hours into an overtime category. This makes it a clear exception_override under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: 5x8 Weekday Straight Time
rule_text:
Five Eight Hour Days (5x8)
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        | 8 hours         | Up to 2 hours              | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 5x8 schedule, the first 8 hours worked on a regular weekday (Monday to Friday) are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> ASSIGN(ST, UP_TO(8))

expected_outcome.condition: The first 8 hours on a regular workday for a 5x8 schedule.

reasoning: This rule establishes the straight time threshold for the 5x8 schedule based on the provided table. It's a foundational 'threshold_based' rule for bucketing worked time.

name: 5x8 Weekday Overtime
rule_text:
Five Eight Hour Days (5x8)
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        | 8 hours         | Up to 2 hours              | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 5x8 schedule, hours worked between 8 and 10 on a regular weekday (Monday to Friday) are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND daily_hours > 8 -> ASSIGN(OT, BETWEEN(8, 10))

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after 8 up to 10 on a regular workday for a 5x8 schedule.

reasoning: This rule defines the first tier of overtime for the 5x8 schedule. It is 'threshold_based' as it triggers after 8 hours and ends at 10 hours.

name: 5x8 Weekday Double Time
rule_text:
Five Eight Hour Days (5x8)
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        | 8 hours         | Up to 2 hours              | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 5x8 schedule, all hours worked in excess of 10 on a regular weekday (Monday to Friday) are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND daily_hours > 10 -> ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after 10 on a regular workday for a 5x8 schedule.

reasoning: This rule defines the double time threshold for the 5x8 schedule. It's 'threshold_based' and follows the ST and OT rules in logical sequence.

name: 4x10 (Mon-Thu) Weekday Straight Time
rule_text:
Four Ten Hour Day Option (4x10) Monday to Thursday:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        | 10 hours        |                            | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a regular workday (Monday to Thursday) are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> ASSIGN(ST, UP_TO(10))

expected_outcome.condition: The first 10 hours on a regular workday (Mon-Thu) for a 4x10 schedule.

reasoning: This rule establishes the straight time threshold for the 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule based on its table. It's a foundational 'threshold_based' rule.

name: 4x10 (Mon-Thu) Weekday Double Time
rule_text:
Four Ten Hour Day Option (4x10) Monday to Thursday:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        | 10 hours        |                            | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, all hours worked in excess of 10 on a regular workday (Monday to Thursday) are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND daily_hours > 10 -> ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after 10 on a regular workday (Mon-Thu) for a 4x10 schedule.

reasoning: This rule defines the double time threshold for the 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule, which notably has no time-and-a-half tier. It is 'threshold_based'.

name: 4x10 (Mon-Thu) Friday Overtime
rule_text:
Four Ten Hour Day Option (4x10) Monday to Thursday:
| Day of Week   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Friday        | Up to 10 hours             | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Friday (a scheduled day off) are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> ASSIGN(OT, UP_TO(10)) AND ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: On a 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule, work on Friday is OT for the first 10 hours, then DT.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' rule specific to Friday for the Mon-Thu 4x10 schedule. It defines the pay structure for a scheduled day off.

name: 4x10 (Tue-Fri) Weekday Straight Time
rule_text:
Four Ten Hour Day Option (4x10) Tuesday to Friday:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Tuesday       | 10 hours        |                            | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a regular workday (Tuesday to Friday) are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> ASSIGN(ST, UP_TO(10))

expected_outcome.condition: The first 10 hours on a regular workday (Tue-Fri) for a 4x10 schedule.

reasoning: This rule establishes the straight time threshold for the 4x10 Tue-Fri schedule based on its table. It's a foundational 'threshold_based' rule.

name: 4x10 (Tue-Fri) Weekday Double Time
rule_text:
Four Ten Hour Day Option (4x10) Tuesday to Friday:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Tuesday       | 10 hours        |                            | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, all hours worked in excess of 10 on a regular workday (Tuesday to Friday) are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND daily_hours > 10 -> ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after 10 on a regular workday (Tue-Fri) for a 4x10 schedule.

reasoning: This rule defines the double time threshold for the 4x10 Tue-Fri schedule, which also has no time-and-a-half tier. It is 'threshold_based'.

name: 4x10 (Tue-Fri) Monday Overtime
rule_text:
Four Ten Hour Day Option (4x10) Tuesday to Friday:
| Day of Week   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        | Up to 10 hours             | After 10 hours     |
summary: For a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Monday (a scheduled day off) are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week == 'MON' -> ASSIGN(OT, UP_TO(10)) AND ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: On a 4x10 Tue-Fri schedule, work on Monday is OT for the first 10 hours, then DT.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' rule specific to Monday for the Tue-Fri 4x10 schedule. It defines the pay structure for a scheduled day off.

name: Saturday Double Time
rule_text: Employees  working  on  a  Saturday,  Sunday,  and  Recognized  Holidays  shall  be  paid  an overtime rate at double (2) time the regular rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on a Saturday are paid at double time, regardless of schedule.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week == 'SAT' -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on any Saturday.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' rule that acts as an override for any standard weekday pay schedule. It applies to all hours on a specific day of the week.

name: Sunday Double Time
rule_text: Employees  working  on  a  Saturday,  Sunday,  and  Recognized  Holidays  shall  be  paid  an overtime rate at double (2) time the regular rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on a Sunday are paid at double time, regardless of schedule.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week == 'SUN' -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on any Sunday.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' rule that acts as an override for any standard weekday pay schedule. It applies to all hours on a specific day of the week.

name: Statutory Holiday Double Time
rule_text: Employees  working  on  a  Saturday,  Sunday,  and  Recognized  Holidays  shall  be  paid  an overtime rate at double (2) time the regular rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on a recognized statutory holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a statutory holiday.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' rule that acts as an override for any standard weekday pay schedule. It applies based on the 'is_stat_holiday' condition.

name: 12hr Shift on 4x10 Base Pay
rule_text: Four (4) x ten (10) Monday to Thursday or Tuesday to Friday: Ten (10) hours @ straight time, two (2) hours @ doubletime (2x)
summary: On a 12-hour shift based on a 4x10 schedule, the day is paid as 10 hours of straight time and 2 hours of double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '12hr_shift' AND base_schedule_type (llm) IN ['4x10_mon_thu', '4x10_tue_fri'] AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> ASSIGN(ST, 10) AND ASSIGN(DT, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: A 12-hour shift on a 4x10 base should have exactly 10 ST and 2 DT.

reasoning: This is a 'schedule_definition' as it dictates a fixed pay structure for a specific, non-standard shift arrangement.

name: 12hr Shift on 5x8 Base Pay
rule_text: Five (5) x eight (8) Monday to Friday: Eight (8) hours @ straight time, two (2) hours at time and one half (1 ½), two (2) hours at doubletime (2x)
summary: On a 12-hour shift based on a 5x8 schedule, the day is paid as 8 hours of straight time, 2 hours of time-and-a-half, and 2 hours of double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '12hr_shift' AND base_schedule_type (llm) == '5x8' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> ASSIGN(ST, 8) AND ASSIGN(OT, 2) AND ASSIGN(DT, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: A 12-hour shift on a 5x8 base should have exactly 8 ST, 2 OT, and 2 DT.

reasoning: This is a 'schedule_definition' as it dictates a fixed pay structure for a specific, non-standard shift arrangement.

name: 4x10 Daily Overtime Thresholds
summary: On a 4x10 schedule, the first 10 hours worked in a day are paid at straight time. All hours worked beyond 10 are paid at double time. There is no time and a half (OT) tier.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10_mon_thu', '4x10_tue_fri'] AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> THRESHOLD(ST, 10) AND AFTER(10, DT)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after 10 on a scheduled day of a 4x10 shift.

reasoning: This is a threshold-based rule as it defines the daily hour limits for ST and the start of DT based on the provided table. It directly impacts how worked time is bucketed.

name: List of Recognized Holidays
rule_text:
The following Recognized Holidays are observed by this Agreement:

| New Year's Day   | Family Day                                |
|------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| Good Friday      | Victoria Day                              |
| Canada Day       | Civic Day                                 |
| Labour Day       | National Day for Truth and Reconciliation |
| Thanksgiving Day | Remembrance Day                           |
| Christmas Day    | Boxing Day                                |

And any other Holiday(s) that may be proclaimed by Federal or Provincial Governments during the life of this Agreement.
summary: This rule lists the specific calendar days that are recognized as statutory holidays under the agreement, including any others proclaimed by government bodies. These are the days eligible for holiday pay rules.
logical_representation: DEFINE(is_stat_holiday, true) FOR dates IN ['New Year's Day', 'Family Day', 'Good Friday', 'Victoria Day', 'Canada Day', 'Civic Day', 'Labour Day', 'National Day for Truth and Reconciliation', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Remembrance Day', 'Christmas Day', 'Boxing Day', 'ANY_PROCLAIMED_HOLIDAY']

expected_outcome.condition: Identifies if a given date is a recognized holiday, which triggers other holiday-related rules.

reasoning: This rule is condition-based because it doesn't bucket hours but instead defines the set of dates that satisfy the 'is_stat_holiday' condition, which is a prerequisite for all other holiday pay rules.

name: Work on a Recognized Holiday
rule_text: Employees working on a Recognized Holiday shall be paid an overtime rate at double (2) time the regular rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on a recognized holiday must be paid at double the employee's regular rate of pay.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL) AND OVERRIDE('daily_threshold_rules')

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a day identified as a recognized holiday.

reasoning: This is a day-based rule because it applies to all hours worked on a specific type of day (a holiday) without any hourly threshold. It acts as an override to any standard weekday bucketing rules.

name: General Weekend Holiday Observance
rule_text: Should any of the above listed holidays (Article 14.02) occur on a Saturday or Sunday, such  holiday  shall  be  observed  on  the  preceding  Friday  or  on  the  Monday  following  unless changed by mutual agreement between the Employer and the Local Lodge Representative.
summary: If a recognized holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the holiday is officially observed (for pay purposes) on the preceding Friday or the following Monday.
logical_representation: IF recognized_holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] -> observed_holiday_date IS preceding 'FRI' OR following 'MON'

expected_outcome.condition: When a holiday's calendar date is a Saturday or Sunday, the 'is_stat_holiday' flag should be applied to the adjacent Friday or Monday instead.

reasoning: This is an exception_override because it changes the default date of holiday observance based on the specific condition of the holiday falling on a weekend. It overrides the calendar date.

name: 4x10 Holiday Week Straight Time Cap
rule_text: When the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is being worked and a Holiday falls during the normal work week the maximum of thirty (30) hours per week shall form the basis of maximum straight time.
summary: In a week with a recognized holiday, employees on a 4x10 schedule can only earn a maximum of 30 straight-time hours for the week. Any hours worked beyond 30 in that week will be overtime.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10_mon_thu', '4x10_tue_fri'] AND week_contains(is_stat_holiday) == true -> THRESHOLD(WEEKLY_ST, 30)

expected_outcome.condition: Total weekly hours exceed 30 in a week containing a holiday for a 4x10 schedule.

reasoning: This is a threshold-based rule because it explicitly sets a maximum number of straight time hours on a weekly basis under the specific condition of a holiday occurring within that week for a 4x10 schedule.

name: 4x10 Mon-Thu Friday Holiday Observance
rule_text: When working the four (4) x ten (10) hour work week Monday to Thursday and the recognized holiday falls on the Friday it will be moved to the preceding Thursday.
summary: For employees on a Monday-Thursday 4x10 schedule, if a recognized holiday falls on the Friday, the holiday is officially observed on the preceding Thursday instead.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND recognized_holiday_date.day_of_week == 'FRI' -> observed_holiday_date IS preceding 'THU'

expected_outcome.condition: For a 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule, when a holiday's calendar date is a Friday, the 'is_stat_holiday' flag should be applied to the preceding Thursday.

reasoning: This rule is an exception_override because it provides a specific holiday observance schedule for the 4x10 Mon-Thu work week that overrides the general observance rules for a holiday falling on a scheduled day off (Friday).

name: 4x10 Mon-Thu Pay on Friday After Observed Thursday Holiday
rule_text: Thursday is the double time day and Friday is the time and one-half day.
summary: When a Friday holiday is observed on the preceding Thursday for a 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule, any hours worked on that Thursday are paid at double time. If work is performed on the Friday (a normal day off), it is paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' AND preceding_day_was_observed_holiday == true -> ASSIGN(OT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a Friday that follows a Thursday observed as a holiday on a 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule.

reasoning: This is a day-based rule as it assigns a specific rate (OT) to all hours worked on a specific day (Friday) under a unique holiday circumstance, overriding any other rules that might apply to a 5th day of work.

name: 4x10 Mon-Thu Weekend Holiday Observance
rule_text: When working the four (4) x ten (10) hour work week Monday to Thursday... If the holiday falls on Saturday or Sunday, it is moved to the following Monday.
summary: For employees on a Monday-Thursday 4x10 schedule, if a recognized holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the holiday is officially observed on the following Monday.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND recognized_holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] -> observed_holiday_date IS following 'MON'

expected_outcome.condition: For a 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule, when a holiday's calendar date is a weekend, the 'is_stat_holiday' flag should be applied to the following Monday.

reasoning: This is an exception_override as it specifies a non-standard holiday observance for the 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule, taking precedence over the general rule that allows observance on Friday or Monday.

name: 4x10 Tue-Fri Monday Holiday Observance
rule_text: When working the four (4) x ten (10) hour work week Tuesday to Friday and the holiday falls on the Monday it is observed on the Tuesday.
summary: For employees on a Tuesday-Friday 4x10 schedule, if a recognized holiday falls on a Monday, the holiday is officially observed on the following Tuesday.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND recognized_holiday_date.day_of_week == 'MON' -> observed_holiday_date IS 'TUE'

expected_outcome.condition: For a 4x10 Tue-Fri schedule, when a holiday's calendar date is a Monday, the 'is_stat_holiday' flag should be applied to Tuesday.

reasoning: This is an exception_override as it defines a specific holiday observance shift for the 4x10 Tue-Fri schedule when a holiday occurs on a non-working day (Monday).

name: 4x10 Tue-Fri Weekend Holiday Observance
rule_text: When working the four (4) x ten (10) hour work week Tuesday to Friday... If it falls on Saturday or Sunday, it is observed on the preceding Friday or on the following Tuesday.
summary: For employees on a Tuesday-Friday 4x10 schedule, if a recognized holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, it is officially observed on either the preceding Friday or the following Tuesday.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND recognized_holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] -> observed_holiday_date IS preceding 'FRI' OR following 'TUE'

expected_outcome.condition: For a 4x10 Tue-Fri schedule, when a holiday's calendar date is a weekend, the 'is_stat_holiday' flag should be applied to the preceding Friday or the following Tuesday.

reasoning: This rule is an exception_override as it specifies observance days (Friday or Tuesday) for a weekend holiday that are unique to the Tue-Fri 4x10 schedule, overriding the general rule's Friday/Monday option.

name: Waiting Time Pay - First Two Days
rule_text: When an employee, on initial hire or transfer to a project, is instructed by the Employer to report to a job location on a certain day but is not placed to work until a later date, they shall be  entitled  to  two  (2)  hours  pay,  plus  subsistence  if  applicable,  for  each  of  the  first  two  (2) regular working days they are kept waiting.
summary: On initial hire or transfer, if an employee is instructed to report but is not put to work, they receive 2 hours of pay for each of the first two regular working days they are kept waiting.
logical_representation: IF (employee_status == 'NEW_HIRE' OR employee_status == 'TRANSFER') AND employee_status == 'WAITING' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND days_waiting <= 2 -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee is waiting for work to start on day 1 or 2 of waiting.

reasoning: This rule defines a specific conditional payment (2 hours) for employees in a 'waiting' status for the first two days. It is a condition_based rule as it depends on employment status and the number of days waited, not on hours worked.

name: Waiting Time Pay - After Two Days
rule_text: Thereafter the waiting pay shall be increased to a full day of pay (i.e. eight (8) hours) for each regular working day.
summary: After waiting for two regular working days, an employee's waiting pay increases to a full 8 hours for each subsequent regular working day until they start work or are released.
depends_on: Waiting Time Pay - First Two Days
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'WAITING' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND days_waiting > 2 -> ASSIGN(ST, 8)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee is waiting for work to start on day 3 or more of waiting.

reasoning: This rule modifies the waiting pay based on a condition (days waited > 2). It's a condition_based rule that follows the initial two-day period.

name: Reporting Time - Inclement Weather, No Work Start
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: If an employee reports to work but cannot start due to bad weather, they are paid a minimum of 2 hours. They must stay on-site for these 2 hours unless told otherwise.
logical_representation: IF work_start_prevented_by_weather == true -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: Work could not start due to inclement weather.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule because the 2-hour payment is triggered by the specific event of 'inclement weather preventing work start', not by hours worked.

name: Minimum Pay - Inclement Weather Work Stoppage
rule_text: When an employee has commenced work and is instructed to stop due to inclement weather, they shall be paid for the actual time worked. In no case shall an employee receive less than two (2) hours of pay.
summary: If work starts but is then stopped due to bad weather, the employee is paid for their actual time worked, with a guaranteed minimum payment of 2 hours for the day.
logical_representation: IF work_stopped_by_weather == true -> ASSIGN(ST, MAX(daily_hours, 2))

expected_outcome.condition: Total pay for the day must be at least 2 hours if work was stopped due to weather.

reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment guarantee (2 hours) under the specific condition that work was stopped due to weather. This makes it a condition_based rule.

name: Reporting Time - Work Not Available
rule_text: When an employee reports  to  work  and  is  not  given  the  opportunity  to  work  because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day of work, they  shall  be  paid  two  (2)  hours  of  reporting  time  and  allowed  to  leave  the  job immediately.
summary: If an employee reports to work as scheduled but no work is available (and they were not notified the previous day), they receive 2 hours of pay.
logical_representation: IF work_available == false AND prior_day_notification_given == false -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee reported to work, but no work was available and no prior notice was given.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule as the 2-hour payment is contingent on two conditions: no work being available and no prior notification.

name: Minimum Pay - General Work Stoppage
rule_text: When an employee has started to work on their regular shift and is instructed to stop, they shall be paid for the actual time worked. In no case shall the employee receive less than two (2) hours of pay.
summary: If an employee starts their shift and is later instructed by the employer to stop working, they are paid for their actual time worked, with a guaranteed minimum of 2 hours for that day.
logical_representation: IF instructed_to_stop_work == true -> ASSIGN(ST, MAX(daily_hours, 2))

expected_outcome.condition: Total pay for the day must be at least 2 hours if employee was instructed to stop work after starting.

reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment guarantee (2 hours) based on the condition of being instructed to stop work. It is therefore a condition_based rule.

name: Exception - No Minimum Pay if Employee Quits for the Day
rule_text: If an employee stops work for reasons of their own, and without the approval of the Employer, they shall be entitled to pay only for the hours actually worked in the day and minimum conditions shall not apply.
summary: If an employee stops working on their own initiative without employer approval, they are only paid for hours actually worked, and all minimum pay guarantees (like reporting time) are voided.
overrides: Minimum Pay - Inclement Weather Work Stoppage
logical_representation: IF voluntary_work_stoppage == true -> OVERRIDE('Minimum Pay - Inclement Weather Work Stoppage', 'Minimum Pay - General Work Stoppage') AND ASSIGN(ST, daily_hours)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee is paid for actual hours worked only, with no minimums, if they stopped work voluntarily.

reasoning: This rule explicitly states that 'minimum conditions shall not apply', making it a clear exception_override to other rules that provide minimum pay guarantees.

name: Shift Premium on Waiting and Reporting Time
rule_text: When an employee qualifies for reporting or waiting time, such time shall include the regular shift premium when applicable.
summary: Any pay received for waiting or reporting time must also include the applicable shift premium if the employee was scheduled for a premium-eligible shift.
logical_representation: IF (qualifies_for_reporting_time == true OR qualifies_for_waiting_time == true) AND shift_type == 'NIGHT' -> APPLY_SHIFT_PREMIUM

expected_outcome.condition: The rate of pay for waiting/reporting hours should be increased by the shift premium if applicable.

reasoning: This rule modifies the *rate* of pay for waiting/reporting hours based on a condition (applicability of a shift premium). It is a condition_based rule affecting the final pay calculation, not the hours themselves.

name: Exception - No Reporting Pay with 8-Hour Notice
rule_text: When  an  employee  is  notified  eight  (8)  hours  prior  to  the  commencement  of  the scheduled starting time not to report for work, then such employee will not be entitled to any reporting time.
summary: An employee is not entitled to reporting pay if the employer notifies them not to report for work at least 8 hours before their shift's scheduled start time.
overrides: Reporting Time - Inclement Weather, No Work Start
logical_representation: IF is_camp_provided == false AND notification_time_prior_to_shift_hours >= 8 -> OVERRIDE('Reporting Time - Inclement Weather, No Work Start', 'Reporting Time - Work Not Available')

expected_outcome.condition: No reporting time should be paid if 8+ hours notice was given for a non-camp job.

reasoning: This rule provides a specific condition (8+ hours notice) that negates the reporting time entitlements. It is a clear exception_override to the reporting pay rules.

name: Exception - No Reporting Pay with 1-Hour Notice on Camp Jobs
rule_text: On camp jobs, the notice time may be reduced to one (1) hour prior to starting time.
summary: For employees on camp jobs, the notification period to cancel a shift without paying reporting time is reduced to 1 hour before the shift starts.
overrides: Reporting Time - Inclement Weather, No Work Start
logical_representation: IF is_camp_provided == true AND notification_time_prior_to_shift_hours >= 1 -> OVERRIDE('Reporting Time - Inclement Weather, No Work Start', 'Reporting Time - Work Not Available')

expected_outcome.condition: No reporting time should be paid if 1+ hours notice was given for a camp job.

reasoning: This rule modifies the standard notification exception for a specific condition (camp jobs), making it a more specific exception_override.

name: Layoff Option for Frequent Shift Cancellations
rule_text: If this occurs more than twice in any one week, Monday through Friday, then the employee shall, at their option, be entitled to a layoff, however, this does not pertain to the normal Christmas break (i.e. two (2) weeks).
summary: If an employee is told not to report for work more than twice in a single Monday-to-Friday week, they have the option to accept a layoff. This does not apply during the Christmas break.
logical_representation: IF cancellations_in_week > 2 AND day_of_week IN ('MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI') AND is_christmas_break == false -> PROVIDE_LAYOFF_OPTION

expected_outcome.condition: An employee right (layoff option) is triggered if they are cancelled more than twice in a work week.

reasoning: This rule defines an employee right that is triggered by a specific condition (more than two cancellations in a week). While not a direct pay calculation, it's a condition_based rule governing employment status derived from timekeeping events.

name: Exception - No Reporting Pay During Strike
rule_text: When an employee is unable to report for work due to a strike or work stoppage on the project where they are employed, such employee will not be entitled to any reporting time.
summary: Employees are not eligible for reporting pay if they are unable to work due to a strike or other work stoppage on their project.
overrides: Reporting Time - Inclement Weather, No Work Start
logical_representation: IF work_prevented_by_strike == true -> OVERRIDE('ALL_REPORTING_TIME_RULES')

expected_outcome.condition: No reporting time is payable if work is unavailable due to a strike.

reasoning: This rule provides a clear condition (strike) that negates all reporting time entitlements, making it a high-level exception_override.

name: Injury Pay Guarantee - Non-Lost Time Accident
rule_text: If it is not a lost time accident covered by Workers' Compensation, they shall also be paid for the remaining unworked normal daily hours for that day (e.g. eight (8) hours, or in case of a compressed work day  ten (10) hours) at the applicable rate.
summary: If an employee is injured on the job and cannot continue working, but it is not a 'lost time' accident covered by WCB, they will be paid for their full scheduled shift for that day (e.g., 8 or 10 hours).
logical_representation: IF is_workplace_injury == true AND is_wcb_lost_time_accident == false -> ASSIGN(ST, scheduled_daily_hours)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee should be paid for their full shift if they leave early due to a non-lost-time injury.

reasoning: This rule guarantees a full day's pay under the specific conditions of a non-lost-time workplace injury. It is a condition_based payment rule.

name: Camp Room Move Pay - During Work Hours
rule_text: Should an employee residing in camp accommodation be requested by the Employer or the Clients' designated camp management personnel to move to another room or camp, they are to do it during work hours and will be paid at appropriate rates...
summary: If an employee living in a camp is required to move rooms, this should be done during their normal, paid working hours.
logical_representation: IF is_camp_provided == true AND camp_room_move_request_during_hours == true -> TIME_IS_WORKED_TIME

expected_outcome.condition: Time spent moving rooms during the workday is regular paid time and should be bucketed normally.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule stating that a specific activity (moving rooms) is considered compensable work time if it occurs during work hours, subject to standard pay rules.

name: Camp Room Move Pay - Outside Work Hours
rule_text: Should an employee residing in camp accommodation be requested by the Employer or the Clients' designated camp management personnel to move to another room or camp, ... the employee shall be paid two (2) hours at the applicable straight time rate to carry out the move, if done outside work hours.
summary: If an employee living in a camp is required to move rooms outside of their regular working hours, they must be paid 2 hours at their straight-time rate for doing so.
logical_representation: IF is_camp_provided == true AND camp_room_move_request_outside_hours == true -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee should receive 2 hours ST if required to move camp rooms outside of work hours.

reasoning: This rule grants a specific payment (2 hours ST) based on the condition of moving rooms outside of work hours. This is a clear condition_based entitlement.

name: Exception - No Pay for Camp Room Move at End of Cycle
rule_text: This provision will not apply where employees are required to pack their room at the end of a work  cycle or to facilitate a move  that will occur during the employees  furlough.
summary: The payment for moving rooms does not apply if the move is part of the normal end-of-cycle pack-up or in preparation for a move during the employee's time off.
depends_on: Camp Room Move Pay - Outside Work Hours
overrides: Camp Room Move Pay - Outside Work Hours
logical_representation: IF is_camp_provided == true AND is_end_of_work_cycle == true -> OVERRIDE('Camp Room Move Pay - Outside Work Hours')

expected_outcome.condition: No payment should be made for packing up a camp room at the end of a work cycle.

reasoning: This rule explicitly states that the room move payment provision 'will not apply' under specific circumstances, making it an exception_override to the camp room move pay rule.

name: Late Pay Penalty on Termination
rule_text: Should the Employer fail to comply with this provision (excluding the reference to the Record of Employment), the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates for each day they are kept waiting exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays up to a maximum of forty (40) hours of pay.
summary: If an employee is laid off or discharged and the employer fails to provide payment by the next regular pay period, the employee is entitled to a penalty of 8 straight-time hours for each business day they are kept waiting, up to a maximum of 40 hours.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] AND late_payment_days (llm) > 0 -> ASSIGN(ST, MIN(late_payment_days (llm) * 8, 40))

expected_outcome.condition: When employer is late paying a terminated employee, 8 hours per business day of delay are added, capped at 40 hours.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule because it's triggered by a specific event (late payment on termination), not by hours worked. It's classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it results in payable straight-time hours being added to an employee's record.

name: Late Pay Penalty on Quit
rule_text: If the Employer fails to comply with this requirement within five (5) working days after the specified pay day, the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates.
summary: If an employee quits and the employer fails to provide payment within five working days after the next regular payday, the employee is entitled to a one-time penalty payment of 8 straight-time hours.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND payment_delay_working_days (llm) > 5 -> ASSIGN(ST, 8)

expected_outcome.condition: When employer is more than 5 working days late paying a quitting employee, a flat 8 hours of ST are added.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule triggered by the employer missing a payment deadline for a quitting employee. It results in a fixed amount of payable straight-time hours, so it's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement (>3 Years Service)
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of continuous service with one (1) Employer,  the  employee  will  be  entitled  to  bereavement  pay  benefits  of  eight  (8)  hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a results  of  the  employee's  attendance  at  a  funeral  or  memorial  service  upon  the  dea th  of  an employee's  Spouse,  Child,  Parent,  Parent -in-Law,  Grandparent  or  Sibling.  Bereavement  Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: Until Dec 31, 2025, employees with over 3 years (36 months) of continuous service are entitled to up to 3 days of bereavement pay (8 hours per day at straight time) for lost work to attend a funeral/memorial for an immediate family member.
logical_representation: IF is_bereavement_leave (llm) == true AND continuous_service_months (llm) > 36 -> ASSIGN(ST, MIN(bereavement_leave_days (llm), 3) * 8)

expected_outcome.condition: When an eligible employee (>36 months service) takes bereavement leave, they should be paid 8 hours ST per day for up to 3 days.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule that grants paid leave (ST hours) based on employee eligibility (service length) and a specific life event. It's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it defines a compensable time entitlement. It has an end date because the service requirement changes.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement (>30 Months Service) eff 2026
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of continuous service with one (1) Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits... Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate. January 1, 2026, continuous employment transitions to thirty (30) months.
summary: Effective Jan 1, 2026, the service requirement for bereavement pay (up to 3 days at 8 hours ST) is reduced to 30 months of continuous service.
logical_representation: IF is_bereavement_leave (llm) == true AND continuous_service_months (llm) > 30 -> ASSIGN(ST, MIN(bereavement_leave_days (llm), 3) * 8)

expected_outcome.condition: Effective Jan 1, 2026, when an eligible employee (>30 months service) takes bereavement leave, they should be paid 8 hours ST per day for up to 3 days.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule updating the eligibility for a paid leave entitlement. It's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it grants compensable time. It's a separate rule due to the change in the service requirement on a specific date.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement (>24 Months Service) eff 2027
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of continuous service with one (1) Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits... Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate... January 1, 2027, continuous employment transitions to twenty-four (24) months.
summary: Effective Jan 1, 2027, the service requirement for bereavement pay (up to 3 days at 8 hours ST) is reduced to 24 months of continuous service.
logical_representation: IF is_bereavement_leave (llm) == true AND continuous_service_months (llm) > 24 -> ASSIGN(ST, MIN(bereavement_leave_days (llm), 3) * 8)

expected_outcome.condition: Effective Jan 1, 2027, when an eligible employee (>24 months service) takes bereavement leave, they should be paid 8 hours ST per day for up to 3 days.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule updating the eligibility for a paid leave entitlement. It's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it grants compensable time. It's a separate rule due to the change in the service requirement on a specific date.

name: Inclement Weather Reporting Time
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: If an employee reports for work but is unable to start due to inclement weather, they are entitled to two hours of reporting time pay. They must stay on site for these two hours unless told otherwise.
logical_representation: IF employee_reported_to_work (llm) == true AND employee_commenced_work (llm) == false AND work_stopped_due_to_inclement_weather (llm) == true AND daily_hours == 0 -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: A minimum of 2 hours should be paid as ST when an employee reports but cannot start work due to weather.

reasoning: This rule establishes a conditional minimum pay entitlement (reporting time) based on specific circumstances (reporting to work, no work started, bad weather). It's a 'condition_based' rule within the 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME' topic as it dictates payable hours.

name: Inclement Weather Minimum Pay After Work Start
rule_text: When an employee has commenced work and is instructed to stop due to inclement weather, they shall be paid for the actual time worked. In no case shall an employee receive less than two (2) hours pay.
summary: If an employee starts working and is then stopped by the employer due to bad weather, they are paid for their actual hours worked, with a minimum guarantee of two hours' pay.
logical_representation: IF employee_commenced_work (llm) == true AND work_stopped_due_to_inclement_weather (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(ST, MAX(daily_hours, 2))

expected_outcome.condition: Total pay must be at least 2 hours when work starts but is stopped due to weather.

reasoning: This is a conditional minimum pay guarantee. It's 'condition_based' because it applies only when work has commenced and is then stopped for a specific reason (inclement weather). It falls under 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME' as it ensures a minimum number of payable hours.

name: Work Not Available Reporting Time
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and is not given the opportunity to work because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day's work, they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and allowed to leave the job immediately.
summary: If an employee reports to work as scheduled but no work is available, and they were not notified in advance, they receive two hours of reporting time pay and can leave immediately.
logical_representation: IF employee_reported_to_work (llm) == true AND work_was_available (llm) == false AND was_notified_not_to_report (llm) == false AND daily_hours == 0 -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: A minimum of 2 hours should be paid as ST when an employee reports but no work is available, without prior notification.

reasoning: This rule outlines a specific entitlement based on a set of conditions (reporting for work, no work available, no prior notice). It is therefore 'condition_based' and part of 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME' as it results in payable hours without work being performed.

name: General Work Stoppage Minimum Pay
rule_text: When an employee has started to work on their regular shift and is instructed to stop, they shall be paid for the actual time worked. In no case shall the employee receive less than two (2) hours pay.
summary: If an employee starts their shift and is later instructed by the employer to stop for any reason, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay, or their actual hours worked if greater.
logical_representation: IF employee_commenced_work (llm) == true AND employer_instructed_stop (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(ST, MAX(daily_hours, 2))

expected_outcome.condition: Total pay must be at least 2 hours when work starts but is stopped by the employer.

reasoning: This rule is a broader version of the inclement weather minimum. It is 'condition_based' because it triggers when an employee is instructed to stop working. It belongs to 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME' as it establishes a floor for payable hours in a day.

name: Voluntary Stoppage Forfeits Minimum Pay
rule_text: If an employee stops work for reasons of their own, and without the approval of the Employer, they shall be entitled to pay only for the hours actually worked in the day and minimum conditions shall not apply.
summary: If an employee leaves work voluntarily without the employer's permission, they forfeit any right to reporting time or minimum pay guarantees and are only paid for the hours they actually worked.
depends_on: Inclement Weather Minimum Pay After Work Start
overrides: Inclement Weather Minimum Pay After Work Start
logical_representation: IF employee_stopped_work_voluntarily (llm) == true -> OVERRIDE('Inclement Weather Reporting Time', 'Inclement Weather Minimum Pay After Work Start', 'Work Not Available Reporting Time', 'General Work Stoppage Minimum Pay')

expected_outcome.condition: Minimum pay guarantees are voided, and only actual hours worked are paid.

reasoning: This rule explicitly states that 'minimum conditions shall not apply' under a specific circumstance (employee quits for the day). This makes it a clear 'exception_override' that negates the previously defined reporting time and minimum pay rules.

name: Long Term Crew - Compressed Work Week Schedule Definition
rule_text: The parties to this Agreement agree that the maximum of nine (9) hours shall constitute a normal days work beginning at 7:30 a.m. and ending at 5:00 p.m. (excluding a one-half hour (1/2) lunch break) may be utilized if restricted to Long Term Base Crew employees. ... the maximum normal work week shall be forty-five (45) hours beginning Monday at 7:30 a.m. and ending Friday at 5:00 p.m.
summary: For Long Term Base Crew employees, the normal work schedule is a compressed work week of five 9-hour days, Monday to Friday, totaling 45 hours.
logical_representation: IF employee_term (llm) == 'long_term_base_crew' -> DEFINE(schedule_type, '5x9', {days: ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'], hours: 9})

expected_outcome.condition: Defines the 5x9 work week for long term crew.

reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental work schedule for a specific group of employees, classifying it as a 'schedule_definition' under 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME'.

name: Long Term Crew - 5x9 Straight Time
rule_text: the maximum of nine (9) hours shall constitute a normal days work
summary: For Long Term Base Crew employees on a compressed work week, the first 9 hours worked on a regular weekday are paid at straight time.
depends_on: Long Term Crew - Compressed Work Week Schedule Definition
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x9' AND is_scheduled_work_day == true AND employee_term (llm) == 'long_term_base_crew' -> ASSIGN(ST, UP_TO(9))

expected_outcome.condition: For the first 9 hours on a scheduled workday for long term crew.

reasoning: This rule establishes the straight time hour threshold for a normal workday under the compressed schedule, making it a 'threshold_based' rule for 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME'.

name: Definition of Long Term Crew
rule_text: when an employee is hired with the intentions of an employment term of more than a six (6) week period, that employee will be automatically on the aforementioned Compressed Work Week arrangements and be considered as a Long Term Base Crew employee.
summary: An employee intended for employment longer than six weeks is classified as a 'Long Term Base Crew' employee.
logical_representation: IF intended_employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 -> SET(employee_term (llm), 'long_term_base_crew')

expected_outcome.condition: Sets the employee classification based on intended hire duration.

reasoning: This rule defines the condition (intended employment duration) that determines an employee's classification, which in turn dictates which pay rules apply. It is a foundational 'condition_based' rule.

name: Short Term Crew - Ninth Hour Overtime
rule_text: It is understood that when employees are hired with the intentions of short-term employment (defined as less than six (6) weeks from the date of hire) that they will be paid time and one-half (1 1/2) for the ninth (9th) hour.
summary: Short-term employees (hired for less than 6 weeks) are paid straight time for the first 8 hours and time and a half for the 9th hour.
logical_representation: IF employee_term (llm) == 'short_term' -> ASSIGN(ST, UP_TO(8)) AND ASSIGN(OT, BETWEEN(8, 9))

expected_outcome.condition: For the 9th hour worked by a short-term employee.

reasoning: This rule sets a specific overtime condition based on a daily hour threshold for a particular employee class, making it a 'threshold_based' rule for 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME'.

name: Short Term to Long Term Crew Conversion
rule_text: Should the employee be employed onsite after six (6) weeks on the job, that employee will then be considered part of the Long Term Crew and paid in in accordance with the Compressed Work Week payment terms (except as outlined in item (e) below).
summary: If a short-term employee works for more than six weeks, their status changes to 'Long Term Crew' and they are paid under the compressed work week rules, unless on a Plant Shutdown.
depends_on: Short Term Crew - Ninth Hour Overtime
logical_representation: IF employee_term (llm) == 'short_term' AND employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 -> SET(employee_term (llm), 'long_term_base_crew')

expected_outcome.condition: Changes employee status from short-term to long-term after 6 weeks.

reasoning: This rule describes a change in an employee's status based on a condition (time on the job), which alters their pay rules. This is a 'condition_based' rule that effectively overrides their initial classification.

name: Work on Scheduled EDO
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the scheduled eighteen (18) days off will be at time and one half (1 ½) for the first twelve (12) hours and double-time (2) paid thereafter.
summary: Work performed on a scheduled Earned Day Off (EDO) is paid at time and a half for the first 12 hours and double time for all hours thereafter.
logical_representation: IF is_scheduled_edo (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(OT, UP_TO(12)) AND ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(12))

expected_outcome.condition: For the first 12 hours worked on a scheduled EDO.

reasoning: This rule applies to a special type of day (scheduled EDO) and has its own hour thresholds, making it a 'threshold_based' rule that acts as a day-based override.

name: Sunday and Stat Holiday Double Time
rule_text: Double-time (2) will be paid for all hours worked on Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: All hours worked on a Sunday or a Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
overrides: Short Term Crew - Ninth Hour Overtime
logical_representation: IF day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked on a Sunday or Statutory Holiday.

reasoning: This rule is a classic 'day_based' override for 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME', as it applies a single rate to all hours worked on specific, entire days, superseding any regular hourly thresholds.

name: Unscheduled Work on Flex EDO
rule_text: If an employee is asked to work their scheduled flex day off without being given forty- eight (48) hours notice, then the employee will be paid overtime at time and one half (1 ½) for up to twelve (12) hours except on Sundays and Statutory Holidays where double-time (2) will be paid for all hours worked.
summary: If an employee works on a flex EDO with less than 48 hours' notice, they are paid time and a half for the first 12 hours, unless that day is a Sunday or Stat Holiday, in which case all hours are double time.
depends_on: Sunday and Stat Holiday Double Time
logical_representation: IF is_flex_edo (llm) == true AND overtime_type == 'UNSCHEDULED' AND day_of_week != 'SUN' AND is_stat_holiday == false -> ASSIGN(OT, UP_TO(12))

expected_outcome.condition: For up to 12 hours worked on a flex EDO with less than 48 hours notice (and not a Sun/Stat).

reasoning: This rule applies based on multiple conditions (day type, notice period), making it 'condition_based'. It also has a threshold, but the primary trigger is the set of conditions.

name: Termination Payout for Unused Flex EDO
rule_text: If a long term employee is terminated without having a flex EDO within the previous six (6) weeks, then an adjustment will be made to pay any regular hours worked in excess of two hundred and forty (240) hours over the previous six (6) weeks at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: Upon termination, a long-term employee who hasn't taken a flex EDO in the last 6 weeks will be paid out for all regular hours worked beyond 240 in that period at the overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_term (llm) == 'long_term_base_crew' AND employee_status == 'TERMINATED' AND flex_edo_taken_in_last_6_weeks (llm) == false -> ASSIGN(OT, regular_hours_in_last_6_weeks (llm) - 240)

expected_outcome.condition: A final pay adjustment for banked EDO hours upon termination under specific conditions.

reasoning: This is a special payout rule triggered by a specific set of conditions related to employment end, not daily work. It's classified as 'condition_based'.

name: Plant Shutdown Schedules for Short Term Crew
rule_text: During a period of Plant Shutdown, all employees hired with the intentions of short- term employment shall be paid based on five (5) eight (8) hour days Monday to Friday or four (4) ten (10) hour days Monday to Thursday and or Tuesday to Friday.
summary: During a plant shutdown, short-term employees work either a 5x8 (Mon-Fri) or a 4x10 (Mon-Thu or Tue-Fri) schedule.
logical_representation: IF project_phase (llm) == 'plant_shutdown' AND employee_term (llm) == 'short_term' -> ALLOW(schedule_type, ['5x8', '4x10_mon_thu', '4x10_tue_fri'])

expected_outcome.condition: Defines the allowable schedules for short term crew during a shutdown.

reasoning: This rule defines the valid work schedules under the specific condition of a Plant Shutdown, making it a 'schedule_definition'.

name: Plant Shutdown Exception for Crew Conversion
rule_text: Those hired for the Plant Shutdown will continue to receive compensation under the terms of short term employment until the conclusion of the work even if they are on site longer than six (6) weeks.
summary: Employees hired specifically for a Plant Shutdown remain classified as 'short-term' for pay purposes for the project's duration, regardless of whether they work longer than six weeks.
depends_on: Short Term to Long Term Crew Conversion
overrides: Short Term to Long Term Crew Conversion
logical_representation: IF hired_for_shutdown (llm) == true -> OVERRIDE('Short Term to Long Term Crew Conversion')

expected_outcome.condition: Ensures shutdown hires remain 'short_term' regardless of duration.

reasoning: This rule explicitly overrides another rule (the 6-week conversion) under a specific circumstance (hired for shutdown), making it a clear 'exception_override'.

name: Plant Shutdown Confirmation for Long Term Crew
rule_text: All Long Term Base Crew employees shall remain on the compensation terms of the Compressed Work Week arrangements where applicable overtime payments will be made for work on a scheduled day off as per Clause c).
summary: During a Plant Shutdown, Long Term Base Crew employees are not affected by the shutdown-specific rules and continue to be paid under their normal Compressed Work Week terms.
logical_representation: IF project_phase (llm) == 'plant_shutdown' AND employee_term (llm) == 'long_term_base_crew' -> IGNORE_RULESET('shutdown_rules')

expected_outcome.condition: Confirms that shutdown-specific rules for short-term employees do not apply to long-term employees.

reasoning: This rule acts as a clarifying exception, preventing the application of shutdown-specific rules to the long-term crew. It functions as an 'exception_override' by walling off one set of rules from a specific group.

name: 9/80 Schedule Applicability (Worksites)
rule_text:
APPROVED WORKSITES FOR THE 9/80 SCHEDULE

- □ Shell Scotford, Ft. Saskatchewan, Alberta
- □ Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer, Redwater, Alberta
- □ Northwest Redwater, Alberta

reasoning: This rule defines a primary condition for the applicability of the entire 9/80 schedule appendix based on project location. It's classified as 'condition_based' because its activation depends on a specific, non-time-based criterion (the worksite).

name: 9/80 Schedule Inapplicability (Shutdowns)
rule_text: It is intended for on-going work and does not operate in 'major shutdown' situations.
