summary: On a regular workday (Monday-Friday), all hours worked after the 10th hour are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_scheduled_work_day == true AND daily_hours > 10 -> ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10.0))

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked beyond 10 on a Monday to Friday.

reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of overtime, which is double time. It's 'threshold_based' because it is triggered after exceeding 10 daily hours.

name: IOL Strathcona Scheduled EDO Double Time
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's will be paid at double-time (2x).
summary: All hours worked on a scheduled Earned Day Off (EDO) are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_scheduled_edo (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked on a designated EDO.

reasoning: This rule applies to a specific type of day (EDO), making it 'day_based'. It overrides the standard weekday rules, assigning all hours directly to double time.

name: IOL Strathcona Saturday Double Time
rule_text: O/Time Pay'ts Sat DT (x2)
summary: All hours worked on a Saturday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week == 'SAT' -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked on a Saturday.

reasoning: This rule is 'day_based' because it applies to all hours worked on a specific day of the week, Saturday, and overrides any standard weekday logic.

name: IOL Strathcona Sunday Double Time
rule_text: O/Time Pay'ts Sun DT (x2)
summary: All hours worked on a Sunday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week == 'SUN' -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked on a Sunday.

reasoning: Similar to the Saturday rule, this rule is 'day_based' because it applies to all hours worked on a Sunday, overriding standard weekday logic.

name: Agreement Validity Period
rule_text: The following formula will be used for the determination of Long and Short Term Maintenance Base Rates and Benefits for the duration of the Agreement: January 1, 2025December 31, 2028.
summary: This agreement, including its wage and benefit formulas, is effective from January 1, 2025, to December 31, 2028.
logical_representation: VALIDATE(current_date >= '2025-01-01' AND current_date <= '2028-12-31')

expected_outcome.condition: Rule applies only to work performed between Jan 1, 2025 and Dec 31, 2028.

reasoning: This rule defines the date range of applicability for all other rules in the agreement, making it a foundational condition for any labor time validation.

name: Compressed Work Week Rate Calculation Reference
rule_text: Compressed Work Week Rates will be calculated pursuant to Article 17.000 of the Agreement.
summary: The rules for calculating pay and bucketing hours on a Compressed Work Week schedule are located in Article 17.000 of this Agreement.
logical_representation: IF is_compressed_work_week (llm) == true -> APPLY_RULES(Article_17.000)

expected_outcome.condition: When a compressed work week is in effect, the time bucketing logic from Article 17.000 must be used.

reasoning: This rule is a pointer to another set of rules that directly govern how hours are bucketed for specific schedules. It's condition_based because it only applies if the schedule is a compressed work week.

name: Fort McMurray Maintenance Base Rate
rule_text: I) Fort McMurray only: Maintenance Base Rates will be set at 100% of Construction Base Rates plus 100% of appropriate benefits.
summary: For projects located in Fort McMurray, the Maintenance Base Rate is 100% of the Construction Base Rate.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Fort McMurray' -> SET_RATE(maintenance_base_rate (llm), 1.0 * construction_base_rate (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: If project is in Fort McMurray, validate that the correct base rate formula is used.

reasoning: This is a rate calculation rule, which is a key part of labour billing and entitlement. It is classified as condition_based as it depends on the project's geographic location.

name: Outside Fort McMurray Maintenance Base Rate
rule_text: II) Outside of Fort McMurray: Long & Short Term Maintenance Base Rates will be set at $0.75 under Construction Base Rates plus 100% of appropriate benefits.
summary: For projects located outside of Fort McMurray, the Maintenance Base Rate is set at $0.75 less than the Construction Base Rate.
logical_representation: IF project_location != 'Fort McMurray' -> SET_RATE(maintenance_base_rate (llm), construction_base_rate (llm) - 0.75)

expected_outcome.condition: If project is outside Fort McMurray, validate that the correct base rate formula is used.

reasoning: This is the complementary rate calculation rule to the Fort McMurray one. It is classified as condition_based as it depends on the project's geographic location.

name: Apprentice Rate Calculation
rule_text: Apprentice rates are calculated at the percentages provided in the Local Construction Agreement applied to Maintenance Journeyperson Rate.
summary: Apprentice wage rates are calculated as a specific percentage of the Maintenance Journeyperson Rate, with the percentage defined in the Local Construction Agreement.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'APPRENTICE' -> SET_RATE(apprentice_rate (llm), percentage_from_local_agreement (llm) * maintenance_journeyperson_rate (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: If employee is an Apprentice, validate that their rate is calculated based on the Journeyperson rate as per the Local Construction Agreement.

reasoning: This is a wage rate calculation rule specific to an employee class, making it a condition_based entitlement rule.

name: Skill Premium Pay
rule_text: Appropriate skill premiums to be paid in accordance with past maintenance jobsite practice.
summary: Skill premiums must be paid according to the established practices of the specific maintenance jobsite.
logical_representation: IF has_skill_premium (llm) == true -> PAY_PREMIUM(based_on_past_jobsite_practice (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: Validate that any required skill premiums are paid according to historical jobsite practice.

reasoning: This rule defines an entitlement to additional pay. It is condition_based, with the condition being an external factor (past jobsite practice) that must be configured in the validation system.

name: Benefit Code B Calculation Basis
rule_text: B Calculated on straight time and overtime hours worked.
summary: Benefits categorized under Code 'B' are calculated based on the sum of all straight time and overtime hours worked.
logical_representation: IF benefit_code (llm) == 'B' -> CALCULATE_BENEFIT_ON(SUM(ST_hours_worked) + SUM(OT_hours_worked))

expected_outcome.condition: For benefits with Code B, validate the calculation is based on ST and OT hours worked.

reasoning: This is a benefit calculation rule that depends on the output of the time bucketing process (ST/OT hours). It's condition_based on the specific benefit code.

name: Benefit Code C Calculation Basis
rule_text: C Calculated on total hours paid.
summary: Benefits categorized under Code 'C' are calculated based on the total hours paid to the employee, which may include non-worked hours.
logical_representation: IF benefit_code (llm) == 'C' -> CALCULATE_BENEFIT_ON(total_paid_hours (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: For benefits with Code C, validate the calculation is based on total hours paid.

reasoning: This is a benefit calculation rule that depends on total paid hours. It's condition_based on the specific benefit code.

name: Benefit Code D Calculation Basis
rule_text: D Calculated on total wages.
summary: Benefits categorized under Code 'D' are calculated based on the employee's total wages.
logical_representation: IF benefit_code (llm) == 'D' -> CALCULATE_BENEFIT_ON(total_wages (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: For benefits with Code D, validate the calculation is based on total wages.

reasoning: This is a benefit calculation rule that depends on total wages. It's condition_based on the specific benefit code.

name: Employer Fund Contribution Obligation
rule_text: Employers will make appropriate contributions to the following funds for those participating trades which have the provision contained within their respective Industrial Construction Reference Agreement: Building Trades of Alberta, Audiometric Testing, Construction Employee Family Assistance Program (CEFAP), Case Managed Aftercare (CMAC), Rapid Site Access Program (RSAP), Workforce Development Trust Fund (WFDT)
summary: Employers must contribute to specific funds (BTA, Audiometric Testing, CEFAP, CMAC, RSAP, WFDT) for trades whose Industrial Construction Reference Agreement includes this provision.
logical_representation: IF trade_has_fund_provision (llm) == true -> REQUIRE(EMPLOYER_CONTRIBUTION(BTA, Audiometric, CEFAP, CMAC, RSAP, WFDT))

expected_outcome.condition: Validate that required contributions are made for participating trades.

reasoning: This rule defines a financial obligation tied to employment. It is condition_based on whether the specific trade's reference agreement requires these contributions.

name: Benefit Contribution Basis Mapping
rule_text: Benefit contributions based on hours earned in construction will be paid on hours earned in maintenance and contributions based on hours worked in construction will be paid on hours worked in maintenance.
summary: The basis for calculating benefit contributions (i.e., 'hours earned' vs. 'hours worked') for maintenance work must mirror the method specified in the trade's Construction Reference Agreement.
logical_representation: SET benefit_basis_in_maintenance (llm) = benefit_basis_in_construction_agreement (llm)

expected_outcome.condition: Validate that the benefit calculation basis (hours worked vs earned) for maintenance matches the construction agreement.

reasoning: This rule establishes the logic for how benefit calculations should be performed, making it a condition_based rule that aligns maintenance practices with construction ones.

name: Overtime Definition Reference (NMA)
rule_text: Overtime - applies to all positions including non-manuals, as per overtime definitions in NMA or BM Agreement
summary: For all positions except Boilermakers, the rules defining when overtime applies are based on the National Maintenance Agreement (NMA). This contract does not specify the daily or weekly thresholds itself.
logical_representation: IF position_classification != 'BOILERMAKER' -> REQUIRE(source_agreement (llm) == 'NMA')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours identified as overtime must conform to NMA rules.

reasoning: This rule delegates the specific overtime logic to an external agreement (NMA) for all non-Boilermaker trades. It's classified as condition_based because its application depends on the worker's position classification.

name: Overtime Definition Reference (Boilermaker Agreement)
rule_text: Overtime - applies to all positions including non-manuals, as per overtime definitions in NMA or BM Agreement
summary: For all Boilermaker positions, the rules defining when overtime applies are based on the Boilermaker Agreement. This contract does not specify the daily or weekly thresholds itself.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'BOILERMAKER' -> REQUIRE(source_agreement (llm) == 'Boilermaker Agreement')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours identified as overtime must conform to the Boilermaker Agreement rules.

reasoning: This rule delegates the specific overtime logic to the Boilermaker Agreement for all Boilermaker personnel. The precedent for this separation is set by the explicit exceptions in the LOA and Meal allowance clauses and confirmed by the 'All required payments' clause.

name: Double Time Definition Reference (NMA)
rule_text: Double Time - applies to all union positions including non-manuals as per NMA or BM Agreement
summary: For all union positions except Boilermakers, the rules defining when double time applies are based on the National Maintenance Agreement (NMA). This contract does not specify the exact thresholds.
logical_representation: IF position_classification != 'BOILERMAKER' -> REQUIRE(source_agreement (llm) == 'NMA')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours identified as double time must conform to NMA rules.

reasoning: This rule delegates the specific double time logic to an external agreement (NMA) for all non-Boilermaker union trades. It's condition_based as its application depends on the worker's position classification.

name: Double Time Definition Reference (Boilermaker Agreement)
rule_text: Double Time - applies to all union positions including non-manuals as per NMA or BM Agreement
summary: For all Boilermaker positions, the rules defining when double time applies are based on the Boilermaker Agreement. This contract does not specify the exact thresholds.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'BOILERMAKER' -> REQUIRE(source_agreement (llm) == 'Boilermaker Agreement')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours identified as double time must conform to the Boilermaker Agreement rules.

reasoning: This rule delegates the specific double time logic to the Boilermaker Agreement for Boilermaker personnel. The separation of agreements is established by other clauses.

name: Statutory Holiday Definition Reference (NMA)
rule_text: Stat Holidays - follow terms of NMA or BM Agreement
summary: For all union positions except Boilermakers, pay and entitlements for statutory holidays are governed by the terms of the National Maintenance Agreement (NMA).
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true AND position_classification != 'BOILERMAKER' -> REQUIRE(source_agreement (llm) == 'NMA')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked on a statutory holiday must be paid according to NMA rules.

reasoning: This is a day_based rule because it applies to a specific type of day (statutory holiday). It delegates the detailed logic for pay calculation to the NMA for non-Boilermaker trades.

name: Statutory Holiday Definition Reference (Boilermaker Agreement)
rule_text: Stat Holidays - follow terms of NMA or BM Agreement
summary: For all Boilermaker positions, pay and entitlements for statutory holidays are governed by the terms of the Boilermaker Agreement.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true AND position_classification == 'BOILERMAKER' -> REQUIRE(source_agreement (llm) == 'Boilermaker Agreement')

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked on a statutory holiday must be paid according to the Boilermaker Agreement rules.

reasoning: This is a day_based rule as it applies to statutory holidays. It delegates the specific pay calculation logic to the Boilermaker Agreement for all Boilermaker personnel.

name: Billable Orientation and On-boarding Hours
rule_text: Orientation / on-boarding hours are all billable (facilities to be provided by NWR)
summary: All time spent by personnel in project orientation or on-boarding activities is billable and should be paid.
logical_representation: IF activity_type (llm) == 'ORIENTATION' OR activity_type (llm) == 'ONBOARDING' -> ASSIGN(ST, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours coded as 'Orientation' or 'On-boarding' should be bucketed as Straight Time.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule that makes a specific type of non-working time billable. It doesn't set thresholds, but defines an entire activity as payable.

name: Billable Site-Specific Training
rule_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing in this Subsection, any Site specific training will be to Owner's account.
summary: Time spent by personnel in site-specific training is billable to the owner and should be paid.
logical_representation: IF activity_type (llm) == 'SITE_SPECIFIC_TRAINING' -> ASSIGN(ST, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours coded as 'Site-Specific Training' should be bucketed as Straight Time.

reasoning: This is a condition_based rule that makes a specific type of training activity billable. It functions as an exception to the rule about non-billable pre-mobilization training.

name: Non-Billable Pre-Mobilization Training
rule_text: Each member of Supplier Group must have all training prior to arriving at to the Site. No hours may be charged to Owner for Supplier Group members that arrive at Site without the required training.
summary: Time is not billable for workers who arrive on site without having completed their required pre-mobilization training.
logical_representation: IF has_required_training (llm) == false -> VALIDATE(hours_billed == 0)

expected_outcome.condition: If a worker arrives without pre-mobilization training, no hours should be billed until they are compliant.

reasoning: This is an exception_override rule because it establishes a condition (lack of training) that negates the billability of time that might otherwise be considered payable (e.g., orientation).

name: Foreman Minimum Pay Duration on Hire/Transfer
rule_text: he/she will at no time be paid less than the Foreman's rate for which they qualify under  Clause  25.02  (b)  for  a  minimum  of  four  (4)  months  from  date  of  hire  or transfer or until laid off if less than four (4) months.
summary: A newly hired or transferred Foreman on an Industrial project must be paid at least the Foreman's rate for a minimum of four months, unless they are laid off sooner.
logical_representation: IF (employee_status == 'NEW_HIRE' OR employee_status == 'TRANSFER') AND is_foreman == true -> VALIDATE(pay_rate >= foreman_rate FOR MIN(4_months, layoff_date - hire_date))

expected_outcome.condition: Foreman's pay rate must be maintained for the first 4 months of employment or until layoff.

reasoning: This rule establishes a pay rate guarantee for a specific duration under certain conditions (hire/transfer of a foreman). It is 'condition_based'. Although it doesn't define ST/OT/DT buckets, it's categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it governs the rate applied to hours worked, which is essential for payroll validation.

name: Pay Continuity During Employee Transfer
rule_text: Where transfers are permitted above, such transfers shall be working within the jurisdiction of the Union and there shall be no interruption of the Employees' earnings while being transferred.
summary: An employee's earnings must continue without interruption when they are transferred between job sites for the same employer. This does not apply to employees returning from scheduled holidays or compassionate leave to a different site.
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'TRANSFER' -> VALIDATE(earnings_are_continuous)

expected_outcome.condition: Time spent actively transferring between job sites for the same employer must be paid.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' rule that creates a pay entitlement under the specific condition of an employee transfer. It falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it mandates payment for a period of time, ensuring no loss of earnings.

name: Online Orientation Pay Allowance
rule_text: If an Employer requires an employee to complete an employer online orientation, the Employer shall estimate a reasonable amount of time to complete the orientation.  The Employer shall pay an allowance for completing the course equal to the time estimated, to a maximum of four (4) hours, multiplied by the employee's base rate only and payable with the first pay period following the start of work. Payment for online orientation will not attract VSP or any benefit contributions.
summary: Employees must be paid an allowance for completing a mandatory online orientation. The pay is for the employer's estimated time to complete it, up to a maximum of 4 hours at the employee's base rate, and is paid with their first paycheck.
logical_representation: IF requires_online_orientation == true -> ASSIGN(ALLOWANCE, MIN(orientation_estimated_hours, 4)) @ ST_RATE

expected_outcome.condition: When required to take online orientation, employee receives pay for estimated hours up to 4 at their base rate.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' rule creating a special payment allowance. It's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it's payment for time spent on a work-related activity, although it's specifically carved out as an allowance at base rate only, not contributing to benefits.

name: Reporting Pay When Not Engaged (Local)
rule_text: Members of the Union dispatched from the Union office reporting for work at the time and place specified by the Employer and who are not engaged by the Employer shall receive a minimum of two (2) hours locally...reporting pay, plus travel allowance and expense, if applicable.
summary: If a dispatched union member reports for work as specified but is not put to work, they are entitled to a minimum of 2 hours of reporting pay if the job is local (within 300 km).
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'WAITING' AND is_engaged == false AND project_location_distance_km <= 300 -> ASSIGN(ST, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee reports to a local job site (<=300km) as dispatched but is not put to work, resulting in 2 hours of pay.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' minimum pay guarantee (show-up time). It is categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME. It is extracted as a separate rule from the remote version because the condition (distance) and outcome (hours) are different.

name: Reporting Pay When Not Engaged (Remote)
rule_text: Members of the Union dispatched from the Union office reporting for work at the time and place specified by the Employer and who are not engaged by the Employer shall receive a minimum of ... four (4) hours beyond 300 km reporting pay, plus travel allowance and expense, if applicable.
summary: If a dispatched union member reports for work as specified at a site more than 300km away but is not put to work, they are entitled to a minimum of 4 hours of reporting pay.
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'WAITING' AND is_engaged == false AND project_location_distance_km > 300 -> ASSIGN(ST, 4)

expected_outcome.condition: Employee reports to a remote job site (>300km) as dispatched but is not put to work, resulting in 4 hours of pay.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' minimum pay guarantee (show-up time). It is categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME. It is extracted as a separate rule from the local version because the condition (distance) and outcome (hours) are different.

name: Reporting Pay Exception - Prior Notification
rule_text: This Clause does not apply where the Employer has notified the Union(s) in a reasonable time that the Employee is not eligible for hire.
summary: Reporting pay is not required if the employer notified the union in a reasonable time that the dispatched employee was not eligible for hire.
logical_representation: IF prior_notification_given == true -> OVERRIDE('Reporting Pay When Not Engaged (Local)', 'Reporting Pay When Not Engaged (Remote)')

expected_outcome.condition: No reporting pay is due if the employer provided reasonable prior notification of ineligibility.

reasoning: This rule is a classic 'exception_override' that negates the two preceding reporting pay rules under a specific condition. It must be processed after the rules it overrides.

name: B Pressure Welder Alloy Certificate Premium
rule_text: B Pressure Welder with Alloy Certificates receive an additional $3.25 per hour worked.
summary: Welders who are qualified as B Pressure Welders and hold Alloy Certificates are entitled to an additional premium of $3.25 for each hour they work. This applies under both Industrial and Commercial/Institutional agreements for Local 488.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welder_type (llm) == 'B_PRESSURE' AND has_alloy_certificate (llm) == true -> ADD_PREMIUM(3.25, 'PER_HOUR_WORKED')

expected_outcome.condition: When a B Pressure Welder with Alloy certs works.

reasoning: This rule defines a specific monetary entitlement (premium pay) based on employee qualifications. It's classified as condition_based because it requires specific certifications. LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the most suitable topic as it's a direct monetary addition to the value of worked time.

name: Monthly Union Dues Calculation
rule_text: Monthly Union Dues = 3x base rate (maximum Journeyman Rate).
summary: Monthly Union Dues are to be calculated as three times the employee's base rate. The base rate used for this calculation cannot exceed the Journeyman base rate.
logical_representation: CALCULATE DEDUCTION(UNION_DUES, MIN(base_rate (llm), journeyman_base_rate (llm)) * 3)

expected_outcome.condition: For calculating monthly union dues.

reasoning: This is a rule for a monetary deduction. Since it's part of the overall financial calculation tied to labor, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the closest topic. It is condition_based as it relies on the employee's base rate and the journeyman rate as a cap.

name: Fraternal & Building Dues Deduction
rule_text: Fraternal & Building dues 18¢ are earned and to be deducted from wages...
summary: A deduction of $0.18 for Fraternal & Building dues must be made for each hour earned.
logical_representation: CALCULATE DEDUCTION(FRATERNAL_BUILDING_DUES, 0.18 * total_earned_hours (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: For calculating fraternal and building dues based on hours earned.

reasoning: This rule specifies a per-hour deduction based on hours earned, making it a billing condition. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as its calculation is directly tied to the quantity of earned hours.

name: BTA Dues Deduction
rule_text: BTA dues of 6¢ per hour earned to be deducted from wages...
summary: A deduction of $0.06 for BTA dues must be made for each hour earned.
logical_representation: CALCULATE DEDUCTION(BTA_DUES, 0.06 * total_earned_hours (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: For calculating BTA dues based on hours earned.

reasoning: This rule defines another per-hour deduction based on hours earned. It's a billing condition directly related to labor hours, thus classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: UAW&O / National Wellness Contribution Basis (Worked Hours)
rule_text: UA National Wellness & Organization will be paid on hours worked.
summary: Employer contributions to the UA National Wellness & Organization fund must be calculated based on total hours worked (straight time hours + overtime hours), not hours earned.
logical_representation: IF benefit_fund_type (llm) == 'UAWO' -> SET(benefit_calculation_basis (llm), 'HOURS_WORKED')

expected_outcome.condition: When calculating UAW&O or National Wellness contributions.

reasoning: This rule specifies the calculation method for a specific benefit fund. This is a core labor billing rule. The distinction between 'worked' and 'earned' hours is fundamental to validating benefit remittances, making LABOR_WORKED_TIME the correct topic.

name: Industrial Work Benefit Contribution Basis (Default)
rule_text: For INDUSTRIAL work, notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Agreement, all contributions to the separate following trust funds shall be payable by the Employer on the Employee's total actual hours EARNED including overtime.
summary: For all industrial projects, the default rule is that employer contributions to benefit trust funds are calculated based on total hours earned (which includes overtime premiums), unless a specific fund is explicitly required to be calculated on hours worked.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'INDUSTRIAL' -> SET_DEFAULT(benefit_calculation_basis (llm), 'HOURS_EARNED')

expected_outcome.condition: Default calculation basis for benefits on Industrial projects.

reasoning: This is a foundational rule that sets the default calculation method for benefits on a specific project type. It is critical for validating financial remittances related to labor hours, so it falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Commercial/Institutional Work Benefit Contribution Basis (Default)
rule_text: For COMMERCIAL/INSTITUTIONAL work, notwithstanding anything contained else-where in this Agreement, all contributions to the separate following Trust Funds shall be payable by the Employer on the Employees' total actual hours WORKED including overtime.
summary: For all commercial and institutional projects, the default rule is that employer contributions to benefit trust funds are calculated based on total hours worked (a direct sum of hours), unless a specific fund is explicitly required to be calculated on hours earned.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] -> SET_DEFAULT(benefit_calculation_basis (llm), 'HOURS_WORKED')

expected_outcome.condition: Default calculation basis for benefits on Commercial/Institutional projects.

reasoning: Similar to the Industrial rule, this sets the default benefit calculation method for Commercial/Institutional work. It is a key billing rule under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: ISIT and MMDF Contribution Basis Override (Earned Hours)
rule_text: All contributions by the Employer(s) for the ISIT and MMDF plan(s) for both INDUSTRIAL and COMMERCIAL INSTITUTIONAL shall be contributed by the Employer based on the Employee's total actual hours EARNED including overtime.
summary: This rule is an override. Regardless of project type (Industrial or Commercial/Institutional), employer contributions for the ISIT and MMDF plans must always be calculated based on total hours earned, even if the project type's default is 'hours worked'.
logical_representation: IF benefit_fund_type (llm) IN ['ISIT', 'MMDF'] -> SET(benefit_calculation_basis (llm), 'HOURS_EARNED') AND OVERRIDE('Commercial/Institutional Work Benefit Contribution Basis (Default)')

expected_outcome.condition: When calculating ISIT or MMDF fund contributions.

reasoning: This is a classic exception_override rule. It specifically changes the calculation basis for two funds, overriding the general rule for Commercial/Institutional projects. This is a critical rule for ensuring correct benefit calculations.

name: Apprentice Rate Proration
rule_text: Increases will be applied to the Journeyman rate and apprentice rates will be prorated as per the established % of the Journeyman rate.
summary: Apprentice wage rates are not fixed dollar amounts but are calculated as a specific percentage of the current Journeyman rate. The applicable percentage is based on the apprentice's year and trade.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'APPRENTICE' -> CALCULATE WAGE_RATE(journeyman_rate (llm) * apprentice_percentage(apprentice_level (llm)))

expected_outcome.condition: When determining the base wage rate for an apprentice.

reasoning: This rule defines how an apprentice's wage is determined. It's a fundamental condition for labor billing, directly impacting the value of their worked time, hence the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic. It's condition_based as it applies only to apprentices.

name: Apprentice Rate Increase Timing
rule_text: The apprentice's next period increase will become effective on the first pay period following the date the apprentice presents to his Employer the letter received from the Apprenticeship Board notifying them of successful completion of a schooling period unless the apprentice's anniversary date has not been reached. In that case the increase will become effective on the first pay period following the anniversary date.
summary: An apprentice's wage rate increase is triggered on the first pay period after they provide proof of successfully completing a school period. However, if their work anniversary date has not yet passed, the increase is delayed until the first pay period after that anniversary date.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'APPRENTICE' AND pay_period_start_date (llm) > MAX(school_completion_date (llm), anniversary_date (llm)) -> TRIGGER(rate_increase)

expected_outcome.condition: To validate the effective date of an apprentice's pay increase.

reasoning: This rule governs the timing of an apprentice's wage progression, which is a key entitlement. It's a condition-based rule dependent on dates. It directly affects pay calculations, so it belongs under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Welding Test Taker Employee Status
rule_text: In the case that any Journeyman, whose skill is welding, is required to take a customer requested welding test, the Employer agrees that such Journeyman will be in the employ of the Employer while taking such tests and be placed on the payroll and paid any applicable travel allowance.
summary: A Journeyman welder is considered an employee on payroll while taking a required customer welding test and is eligible for any applicable travel allowance.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'JOURNEYMAN' AND position_classification == 'WELDER' AND activity_type (llm) == 'CUSTOMER_WELDING_TEST' THEN VALIDATE(employee_status (Unsupported) == 'EMPLOYEE_ON_PAYROLL')

expected_outcome.condition: Time spent taking a customer welding test is considered paid work time.

reasoning: This rule establishes that time spent in a welding test is paid work time. It's condition_based as it applies only when a Journeyman welder is taking a specific type of test. This is a foundational rule for other payment rules in this article.

name: Welding Test Minimum Pay - Pass Test, No Work
rule_text: Provided that the Employee reports to test at the time scheduled by the Employer, they shall be paid one full day's pay if they pass the test, and the Employer has no work available for them on that day.
summary: If a welder reports for a test on time, passes it, but the employer has no work available for them that day, they are guaranteed one full day's pay.
logical_representation: IF employee_arrival_status (llm) == 'ON_TIME' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'PASS' AND work_availability (llm) == 'NONE' THEN PAY_MINIMUM('REGULAR_DAY_PAY')

expected_outcome.condition: Total pay for the day must equal a full day's pay when the specific conditions are met.

reasoning: This rule provides a minimum pay guarantee under specific conditions (on time, pass test, no work). It is classified as condition_based because it depends on multiple factors, not just hours worked.

name: Welding Test Pay - Late Arrival
rule_text: if an Employee reports after the scheduled test time and passes the test they shall be paid from the time they started the test until the normal end of that shift.
summary: If a welder arrives late for a test but passes, they will be paid only from the time the test began until the end of the normal shift.
overrides: Welding Test Minimum Pay - Pass Test, No Work
logical_representation: IF employee_arrival_status (llm) == 'LATE' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'PASS' THEN ASSIGN(ST, hours_from_test_start_to_shift_end)

expected_outcome.condition: Paid hours should start from the actual test start time, not the scheduled time, if the employee was late.

reasoning: This rule defines the exact paid time for a specific scenario (late arrival). It's condition_based and acts as an override to the full-day pay guarantee for those who are not on time.

name: Welding Test Pay - Fail Test
rule_text: A welder who fails the test shall not be paid for the time required to complete the failed test but will be paid any applicable travel allowance.
summary: A welder who fails a test will not be paid for the time spent on the test, but will still receive any applicable travel allowance.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'FAIL' THEN ASSIGN(UNPAID, hours_for_test) AND PAY(travel_allowance)

expected_outcome.condition: Time spent on a failed welding test must be recorded as unpaid.

reasoning: This is an explicit exclusion rule. It's condition_based on the test result and overrides the general rule that test time is paid time.

name: Welding Test Pay - Multiple Tests, Not Hired
rule_text: In the event the worker is required to take multiple tests and passes some of the tests but fails others they will be paid as above if hired or will be paid for the time taken on successful tests if not hired.
summary: If a welder takes multiple tests, passing some and failing others, and is not hired, they will only be paid for the time spent on the tests they passed.
logical_representation: IF welding_test_count (llm) > 1 AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'MIXED' AND is_hired_after_test (llm) == false THEN ASSIGN(ST, hours_on_successful_tests)

expected_outcome.condition: Only the hours spent on tests that were passed should be bucketed as Straight Time if the worker is not subsequently hired.

reasoning: This rule clarifies payment for a complex scenario (multiple tests with mixed results). It is condition_based on the test outcomes and the hiring decision.

name: Waiting Time Pay for Test Assessment
rule_text: Welders successfully completing such tests shall receive a regular day's pay at straight time rates for any working day lost, due to transportation delays, or when test pieces must be sent to an outside agency for assessment, except when transportation delays are beyond the control of the Employer.
summary: Welders who pass their tests are entitled to a regular day's pay for any workday they lose while waiting for test results from an outside agency or due to transportation delays (unless the delay is beyond the employer's control).
logical_representation: IF welding_test_result (llm) == 'PASS' AND waiting_reason (llm) IN ['ASSESSMENT_DELAY', 'TRANSPORTATION_DELAY'] AND delay_control (llm) == 'EMPLOYER_CONTROL' THEN PAY_MINIMUM('REGULAR_DAY_PAY')

expected_outcome.condition: For a lost workday due to specified delays, pay must equal a regular day's pay at straight time.

reasoning: This rule creates an entitlement for 'waiting time' under specific circumstances. It's condition_based on the test result and the reason for the delay. It also includes an exception, which I have noted in the logical representation.

name: Forfeiture of Pay for Failure to Report to Work
rule_text: Welders, upon successfully completing such tests, who fail to report for work, or fail to commence work when directed, will not be eligible for daily subsistence, travel allowance, transportation, accommodation, waiting, and/or testing time pay.
summary: A welder who passes a test but then does not show up for work or refuses to start work as directed forfeits their entitlement to various payments, including pay for the test time.
overrides: Welding Test Minimum Pay - Pass Test, No Work
Waiting Time Pay for Test Assessment
logical_representation: IF welding_test_result (llm) == 'PASS' AND employee_action (llm) IN ['FAIL_TO_REPORT', 'FAIL_TO_COMMENCE'] THEN FORFEIT(testing_time_pay, travel_allowance, subsistence)

expected_outcome.condition: All testing time and related allowances must be unpaid if the welder fails to report to or commence work after passing the test.

reasoning: This rule is a forfeiture clause that negates other payment entitlements based on the employee's actions after passing a test. It is a clear exception_override.

name: Welding Test Incentive Fee
rule_text: A welder (Journeyman or Apprentice) who is required by the Employer or the Employer's client to perform on any Gas Tungsten Arc Welding (GTAW) test or Gas Metal Arc Welding (GMAW) test or Flux-Core Arc Welding (FCAW) test for pressure welding will be paid a testing fee of one hundred and seventy-five ($175.00) dollars effective May 1, 2013 providing they meet the following criteria: (a) The welder must successfully pass the relevant test. (b) The welder remains on the project a minimum of thirty (30) days or until lay off, whichever occurs first (c) The welder cannot refuse to utilize the tested procedure while employed on the project.
summary: A welder who passes a GTAW, GMAW, or FCAW pressure welding test will receive a $175 fee, provided they stay on the project for at least 30 days (or until layoff) and do not refuse to use the procedure they were tested on. The fee is paid out after the 30-day period or at layoff.
logical_representation: IF welding_test_type (llm) IN ['GTAW', 'GMAW', 'FCAW'] AND welding_test_result (llm) == 'PASS' AND (project_days_worked (llm) >= 30 OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF') AND refused_procedure (llm) == false THEN PAY_FEE($175.00)

expected_outcome.condition: A $175 fee should be paid if all specified conditions (test type, pass, tenure, procedure use) are met.

reasoning: This rule provides a specific flat-fee entitlement based on a set of cumulative conditions. It's classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it relates to a payment for work activity, though it is not hour-based. It is condition_based due to the multiple criteria that must be met.

name: Alloy Welding Premium - Dispatched
rule_text: Welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of $3.25 per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: Welders dispatched specifically for their alloy welding certification will receive an additional $3.25 for every hour they work.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND dispatch_requirement (llm) == 'ALLOY_CERTIFICATION' THEN PAY_PREMIUM($3.25, per_hour_worked)

expected_outcome.condition: A premium of $3.25/hr must be applied to all worked hours if the welder was dispatched for alloy welding.

reasoning: This rule establishes an hourly premium based on a dispatch condition. It's a condition_based rule that modifies the worker's pay rate.

name: Alloy Welding Premium - Re-classified
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to be certified by the employer and is requested to perform alloy welding, the worker will be re-classified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium for all hours worked during the applicable work cycle.
summary: If a welder, not originally dispatched for alloy work, is asked to perform alloy welding, they will be re-classified and paid the alloy premium for all hours worked during that entire work cycle (e.g., the full week).
logical_representation: IF dispatch_requirement (llm) != 'ALLOY_CERTIFICATION' AND is_performing_alloy_welding (llm) == true THEN PAY_PREMIUM($3.25, all_hours_in_work_cycle)

expected_outcome.condition: A premium of $3.25/hr must be applied to all hours in the work cycle if the welder performs any alloy welding.

reasoning: This rule extends the alloy premium based on work performed on-site, not just dispatch conditions. It is condition_based and importantly applies the premium retroactively to the entire work cycle.

name: Work Cycle Definition
rule_text: The work cycle will be defined as the scheduled hours of work and days off per rotation (i.e., for 7-day work cycle, 5 workdays and 2 days off or 4 workdays and 3 days off).
summary: A 'work cycle' is defined as the full rotation of scheduled workdays and days off.
logical_representation: DEFINE work_cycle AS schedule_rotation_period

expected_outcome.condition: This rule defines the time period for other rules, like the re-classification premium.

reasoning: This rule is a pure definition that provides context for other rules, specifically 13.07(b). It is classified as a schedule_definition.

name: Alloy Premium - Third Re-classification
rule_text: The worker may only be reclassified to a maximum of 2 times in a calendar year, if the worker is reclassified a 3rd time within the calendar year the worker is entitled to the premium for all hours worked from the date of the employee being reclassified a 3rd time, until the worker is laid off or terminated.
summary: After a welder is re-classified to an alloy welder for the third time in a calendar year, they are entitled to receive the alloy premium for all hours worked from that point until they are laid off or terminated.
logical_representation: IF reclassification_count_yearly (llm) >= 3 THEN PAY_PREMIUM($3.25, all_hours_from_3rd_reclass_until_layoff_or_termination)

expected_outcome.condition: A premium of $3.25/hr must be applied to all hours worked from the date of the 3rd re-classification until end of employment.

reasoning: This rule creates a long-term entitlement based on the frequency of re-classification. It is condition_based on the number of times a worker is re-classified within a year.

name: Apprentice Provisional Welder Pay Rate
rule_text: When an apprentice in the employ of an employer acquires a Provisional 'C' Welders ticket that allows them to perform pressure welds for that employer that apprentice will be paid at the 'Journeyman Welder without CWB' rate while engaged in that work for their employer.
summary: An apprentice who gets a Provisional 'C' Welder's ticket will be paid at the 'Journeyman Welder without CWB' rate for any hours they spend performing pressure welds.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'APPRENTICE' AND employee_certification (llm) == 'PROVISIONAL_C_TICKET' AND work_type (llm) == 'PRESSURE_WELDING' THEN SET_RATE('JOURNEYMAN_WELDER_WITHOUT_CWB')

expected_outcome.condition: The pay rate for hours worked on pressure welds must be adjusted to the specified Journeyman rate.

reasoning: This rule specifies a pay rate change for an apprentice based on their certification and the specific work they are performing. It is a condition_based rule that modifies the base wage.

name: Recognized Holiday Work at Double Time
rule_text: All work performed on the following recognized holidays, and any general holiday declared by the level of government with jurisdiction, either the Federal or Provincial, shall be paid for at the rate of double time, plus any applicable shift differential, as follows:
summary: All hours worked on a recognized statutory holiday are paid at double the regular rate (DT). Recognized holidays include: New Year's Day, Family Day, Good Friday, Victoria Day, Canada Day, Heritage Day, Labour Day, National Day for Truth & Reconciliation, Thanksgiving Day, Remembrance Day, Christmas Day, and Boxing Day.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a recognized holiday.

reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for an entire day based on its type (a statutory holiday). It overrides any standard daily or weekly threshold rules, making it a 'day_based' rule within the 'LABOR_WORKED_TIME' topic.

name: Prohibition of Work on Labour Day
rule_text: No work shall be performed on Labour Day, except for the preservation of life or imminent danger to property.
summary: Work is prohibited on Labour Day unless it is essential for preserving life or preventing imminent danger to property. If work is performed under these exceptions, it is paid according to the recognized holiday rule (Double Time).
depends_on: Recognized Holiday Work at Double Time
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true AND holiday_name (llm) == 'Labour Day' -> VALIDATE(emergency_work_status (llm) == true)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours submitted on Labour Day should be flagged for verification of emergency conditions.

reasoning: This rule is an exception that prohibits work on a specific holiday. While not a direct pay rule, it's a critical validation constraint for timesheets. It's classified as 'exception_override' because it overrides the general allowance to work on holidays under specific circumstances.

name: Statutory Holiday Pay Accrual (4%)
rule_text: In lieu of pay for the above recognized holidays the Employer shall pay an additional 4% to the Employee's total hourly earnings each week, including overtime hours and premium time hours.
summary: In lieu of receiving pay for unworked holidays, employees receive an additional 4% of their total weekly earnings (including straight time, overtime, and premium hours) as statutory holiday pay.
logical_representation: VALIDATE(statutory_holiday_pay_accrual == 0.04 * total_hourly_earnings)

expected_outcome.condition: Statutory Holiday Pay must be calculated as 4% of total weekly earnings.

reasoning: This rule defines a financial entitlement (4% accrual) rather than bucketing hours. It is classified as condition_based under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it is a form of labor compensation directly tied to earnings from worked time, even if it's a payroll calculation rather than an hour-type validation.

name: Vacation Pay Accrual (6%)
rule_text: Employees annual Vacation Pay shall be 6% of the Employee's total hourly earnings. Such total hourly earnings shall be deemed to include straight time hours, overtime hours, premium time hours and shall be paid each pay period with the Employee's regular pay.
summary: Employees receive 6% of their total earnings (including straight time, overtime, and premium hours) as vacation pay. This amount is paid out on each regular pay period.
logical_representation: VALIDATE(vacation_pay_accrual == 0.06 * total_hourly_earnings)

expected_outcome.condition: Vacation Pay must be calculated as 6% of total earnings.

reasoning: Similar to the statutory holiday pay rule, this defines a financial entitlement (6% accrual). It is classified as condition_based under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it's a core component of labor compensation tied to earnings from worked hours.

name: VHP and SHP Payout Options (Calgary 496)
rule_text: For  the  Calgary  496  jurisdiction  only,  for  Commercial/Institutional  work  only,  the Employer shall have the option to pay V.H.P. and S.H.P. with each pay cheque, or as follows:  at the time vacation is taken;  on the last payday prior to December 31st;  on termination. (b) Whether the Employees receive the above noted holiday and vacation pay each pay period, or whether the vacation and holiday pay are to be retained by the Employer and paid to each Employee ... shall be determined by a majority vote of the Employees of that Employer.
summary: For Commercial/Institutional projects in the Calgary 496 jurisdiction, the standard rule of paying Vacation and Holiday Pay (VHP/SHP) each pay period can be changed. Based on a majority employee vote, the payout can be deferred to when vacation is taken, year-end, or termination.
overrides: Default per-pay-period payout clause of VHP and SHP
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'Calgary 496 jurisdiction' AND project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] -> OVERRIDE('default_vhp_shp_payout_schedule')

expected_outcome.condition: Verifies if the VHP/SHP payout schedule deviates from the default 'per-pay-period' method under the specified jurisdictional and project type conditions.

reasoning: This rule creates a specific exception to the standard payout timing for VHP/SHP based on jurisdiction and project type. It explicitly overrides the default behavior defined in articles 14.04 and 14.05, making it an 'exception_override' rule.

name: Delayed Lunch Break Penalty
rule_text: If the lunch break is delayed such that it starts more than one-half hour after the completion of the normal lunch break, the Employee will be paid an additional one-half hour at their applicable straight time rate for the one-half hour lunch break.
summary: If an employee's unpaid lunch break is delayed by more than 30 minutes from its normal end time, they are paid for the 30-minute break at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF lunch_break_delayed_start_minutes (llm) > 30 -> ASSIGN(ST, 0.5)

expected_outcome.condition: 0.5 hours of ST should be added if the lunch break start is delayed more than 30 minutes past its scheduled completion.

reasoning: This rule defines a conditional payment based on an event (delayed lunch). It's not based on hours worked, so it's 'condition_based'. The outcome is a direct payment, which is best represented as adding hours to the ST bucket.

name: Standard Coffee Breaks
rule_text: All Employees covered by this agreement shall be permitted ten (10) minutes in the first half and ten (10) minutes in the second half of a shift for a coffee break on the job during regular working hours.
summary: Employees are entitled to two 10-minute paid coffee breaks per standard shift, one in each half of the shift.
logical_representation: DEFINE(break_duration, 0.1667) AND DEFINE(break_count, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: Defines the standard duration of a coffee break as 10 minutes (0.1667 hours) for use in missed break calculations.

reasoning: This rule establishes the baseline entitlement for coffee breaks. While not a direct payment rule itself, it defines the parameters (duration) used by the 'Missed Break Penalty' rule. It's a foundational condition.

name: Overtime Coffee Breaks
rule_text: If extended overtime is required, additional coffee breaks shall be permitted during such overtime after each two (2) hours following each overtime meal break.
summary: During extended overtime, employees get an additional coffee break for every two hours worked after an overtime meal.
logical_representation: IF hours_worked_after_ot_meal (llm) >= 2 -> ENTITLEMENT(coffee_break, REPEAT_EVERY_2_HOURS)

expected_outcome.condition: Establishes entitlement to additional breaks during overtime, which can trigger missed break penalties if not provided.

reasoning: This rule defines the condition under which an employee is entitled to extra breaks during overtime. It's 'condition_based' because it depends on 'extended overtime' and working past an 'overtime meal break'. This rule defines the entitlement that the missed break penalty rules would apply to.

name: Industrial CWW Break Duration
rule_text: However, for INDUSTRIAL WORK ONLY and on a compressed work week scheduled pursuant to Article 17.00, Employees shall be permitted a break of fifteen (15) minutes in the first half and fifteen (15) minutes in the second half of such shifts.
summary: For employees on an industrial project working a compressed work week, the two standard coffee breaks are 15 minutes each instead of 10.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'INDUSTRIAL' AND is_compressed_work_week (llm) == true -> OVERRIDE('Standard Coffee Breaks') AND DEFINE(break_duration, 0.25)

expected_outcome.condition: Overrides standard break duration to 15 minutes (0.25 hours) for Industrial CWW schedules.

reasoning: This rule is an 'exception_override' because it explicitly changes the standard 10-minute break rule under specific conditions (INDUSTRIAL project type and Compressed Work Week schedule).

name: 10-Hour Shift Optional Paid Breaks
rule_text: When ten (10) hour shifts are worked, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two breaks of one half (½) hour each, paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On 10-hour shifts, the employer can optionally replace the standard coffee breaks and unpaid lunch with two 30-minute paid breaks.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours == 10 AND employer_10hr_break_option (llm) == true -> OVERRIDE('Standard Coffee Breaks') AND DEFINE(break_duration, 0.5) AND DEFINE(break_count, 2)

expected_outcome.condition: If this employer option is used on a 10-hour day, break entitlement becomes two 30-minute paid breaks.

reasoning: This rule is an 'exception_override' because it provides an optional alternative ('in lieu of') to the standard break and lunch structure, conditional on the shift length and employer's choice.

name: 10-Hour Shift Optional Breaks Exclusion
rule_text: This option shall not be applicable to compressed work weeks for which workdays are regularly scheduled in excess of ten (10) hours.
summary: The option for two 30-minute paid breaks on 10-hour shifts cannot be used on compressed work weeks where shifts are regularly scheduled for more than 10 hours.
logical_representation: IF is_compressed_work_week (llm) == true AND scheduled_daily_hours (llm) > 10 -> OVERRIDE('10-Hour Shift Optional Paid Breaks')

expected_outcome.condition: Disables the '10-Hour Shift Optional Paid Breaks' rule if the schedule is a CWW with days longer than 10 hours.

reasoning: This is a classic 'exception_override'. It explicitly states that a previously defined option ('This option') is not applicable under a more specific set of circumstances.

name: Missed Break Penalty
rule_text: In the event an employee is not able to take a break, the employee shall be paid at applicable overtime rates for the missed break.
summary: If an employee is unable to take an entitled break, they must be paid for the duration of the break at the applicable overtime rate for when the break occurred.
logical_representation: IF is_break_missed (llm) == true -> IF rate_at_time_of_missed_break (llm) == 'DT' THEN ASSIGN(DT, missed_break_duration (llm)) ELSE ASSIGN(OT, missed_break_duration (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: Adds time to the OT or DT bucket equal to the duration of the missed break, based on the rate applicable when the break was missed.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' rule because it triggers on the event of a missed break. It results in a direct payment, modeled as adding hours to the appropriate overtime bucket (OT or DT).

name: Missed Break Penalty during Straight Time Hours
rule_text: When the hour before and the hour following the missed break are at straight tine, time and one half (1 ½ x) shall be paid for the missed break.
summary: This clarifies the missed break penalty: if the hours surrounding the missed break were straight-time hours, the break is paid at time and a half (1.5x OT).
logical_representation: IF is_break_missed (llm) == true AND is_surrounding_hours_st (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(OT, missed_break_duration (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: Ensures a missed break surrounded by ST hours is paid as OT (1.5x), overriding any other 'applicable rate' logic.

reasoning: This rule clarifies and overrides the 'applicable overtime rates' part of the main penalty rule. It sets a specific rate (1.5x) when the surrounding hours are ST, making it an 'exception_override'.

name: Paid Waiting Time for Negative POCT Result
rule_text: If an employer requests a worker to participate in a POCT risk assessment pursuant to 4.8.5 of the Canadian Model , and the worker provides the urine sample, and the laboratory drug test result is negative, the worker shall be paid for any time the worker would have otherwise worked while waiting for the laboratory result, except for such discipline that was justified by the worker's conduct in respect to the incident or reasons for the test request.
summary: An employee will be paid for time spent waiting for a lab drug test result, provided they complied with the initial rapid (POCT) test and the final result is negative.
logical_representation: IF poct_sample_provided (llm) == true AND lab_test_result_negative (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(ST, waiting_time_hours (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: Time spent waiting for a negative lab result after providing a POCT sample should be paid as ST.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' payment rule. The payment for waiting time is contingent on a series of conditions being met (providing a sample, negative result). The pay is for time that would have been 'otherwise worked', so ST is the most logical bucket.

name: Unpaid Waiting Time for Declined POCT
rule_text: If the worker declines to provide the sample for the POCT risk assessment and the laboratory drug test result is negative, the worker shall not be entitled to any pay for time the worker would have otherwise worked while waiting for the laboratory result.
summary: If an employee declines the initial rapid (POCT) test, they will not be paid for the time spent waiting for the full lab result, even if it is negative.
depends_on: Paid Waiting Time for Negative POCT Result
overrides: Paid Waiting Time for Negative POCT Result
logical_representation: IF poct_sample_provided (llm) == false AND lab_test_result_negative (llm) == true -> ASSIGN(UNPAID, waiting_time_hours (llm))

expected_outcome.condition: Overrides the paid waiting time rule, ensuring no payment is made if the employee declines the initial POCT.

reasoning: This is an 'exception_override' because it explicitly negates the entitlement established in the previous sentence under a different condition (declining the POCT). It overrides the 'paid waiting time' rule.

name: 5x8 Schedule Definition
rule_text: The maximum of eight (8) hours shall constitute a normal day's work beginning at 8:00 AM and ending by 5:00 PM (except when one-half (½) hour lunch is taken in which case the normal day will end at 4:30 PM). The maximum normal work week shall be forty (40) hours beginning Monday at 8:00 AM and ending Friday at 5:00 PM.
summary: The standard work schedule is five 8-hour days per week (5x8), totaling 40 hours, from Monday to Friday. The normal workday runs from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM with a one-hour lunch, or 8:00 AM to 4:30 PM with a half-hour lunch.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> DEFINE(schedule_days=['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'], daily_hours=8, weekly_hours=40)

expected_outcome.condition: The first 8 hours worked on a scheduled weekday (Mon-Fri) are straight time.

reasoning: This rule defines the core 5x8 schedule, including the days and hours that constitute a standard work week. It's classified as 'schedule_definition' as it establishes the baseline for all other hour calculation rules.

name: Weekly Straight Time Maximum
rule_text: Forty (40) hours shall constitute a work week, Monday through Friday. All other time worked shall be considered overtime and shall be paid for at the applicable overtime rate of pay.
summary: The standard work week is 40 hours from Monday to Friday. Any hours worked beyond 40 in the week are considered overtime.
logical_representation: IF weekly_hours > 40 -> TRANSITION(OT)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked in excess of 40 per week.

reasoning: This rule establishes the weekly 40-hour threshold for overtime, which is a fundamental 'threshold_based' rule for bucketing hours.

name: General Daily Overtime - First Tier
rule_text: The first two (2) hours of overtime per day, Monday through Friday inclusive, shall be paid at one and one half (1½) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On weekdays (Monday to Friday), the first two hours of work after the standard 8-hour day are paid at time and a half (1.5x). This applies from the 9th to the 10th hour worked.
logical_representation: IF project_type NOT IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] AND daily_hours > 8 -> ASSIGN(OT, UP_TO(2))

expected_outcome.condition: For the 9th and 10th hours worked on a weekday on non-Commercial/Institutional projects.

reasoning: This is a classic 'threshold_based' rule defining the first tier of daily overtime. It's restricted to non-Commercial/Institutional projects due to the specific rule in 16.03(d).

name: General Daily Overtime - Second Tier
rule_text: All other overtime hours, Monday through Friday inclusive, shall be paid at two (2) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On weekdays (Monday to Friday), any hours worked beyond 10 in a day are paid at double time (2x).
logical_representation: IF project_type NOT IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT)

expected_outcome.condition: For all hours worked after the 10th hour on a weekday on non-Commercial/Institutional projects.

reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of daily overtime, which is a transition to Double Time. It follows the first tier, making it a 'threshold_based' rule. It is also restricted to non-Commercial/Institutional projects.

name: General Saturday/Sunday/Holiday Overtime
rule_text: All hours worked on Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays shall be paid at two (2) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time (2x).
logical_representation: IF project_type NOT IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holidays on non-Commercial/Institutional projects.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' override rule. The conditions (specific days of the week or a holiday) trigger a flat rate for all hours, superseding any daily threshold rules. It is restricted to non-Commercial/Institutional projects.

name: Commercial/Institutional Daily/Weekly Overtime
rule_text: All hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours per day or forty (40) hours per week will be considered to be overtime hours and will be paid at the rate of one and one-half times the applicable rate of pay
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects, overtime is paid at time and a half (1.5x) for any hours worked beyond 8 in a single day OR beyond 40 in a week, whichever is greater.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] AND (daily_hours > 8 OR weekly_hours > 40) -> TRANSITION(OT)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours exceeding 8 per day or 40 per week on Commercial/Institutional projects.

reasoning: This is a specific 'threshold_based' rule for Commercial/Institutional projects that overrides the general overtime rules. It combines daily and weekly triggers and has only one tier of overtime (1.5x).

name: Commercial/Institutional Sunday/Holiday Overtime
rule_text: except for work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays which will be paid at double time.
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects, all hours worked on Sundays and Statutory Holidays are paid at double time (2x). Note: Saturdays are not included and are paid per the standard overtime rule.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] AND (day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on Sunday or Statutory Holidays on Commercial/Institutional projects.

reasoning: This is a 'day_based' rule that acts as an exception to the main Commercial/Institutional overtime rule. It specifies that Sundays and holidays are always double time, overriding the 1.5x OT rate for those specific days.

name: Pre-Shift Work as Overtime
rule_text: When an Employee is required to work prior to the commencement of their regular shift, such time shall be considered as overtime.
summary: Any time an employee works before their scheduled start time is considered overtime and paid at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF work_start_time (llm) < scheduled_shift_start_time (llm) -> ASSIGN(OT, hours_worked_before_shift)

expected_outcome.condition: For any hours worked before the employee's regular shift is scheduled to begin.

reasoning: This rule defines a specific condition for classifying hours as overtime. It's 'condition_based' because it depends on the timing of work relative to the schedule, not on the total number of hours worked.

name: CWW 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule Definition
rule_text: The maximum of ten (10) hours shall constitute a normal day's work... The maximum normal work week shall be forty (40) hours beginning Monday at 7:00 AM and ending Thursday at 6:00 PM.
summary: Defines the standard compressed work week as four 10-hour days, Monday to Thursday, for a total of 40 straight-time hours per week.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] -> DEFINE_SCHEDULE(daily_hours=10, weekly_hours=40)

expected_outcome.condition: First 10 hours on Monday-Thursday on a 4x10 schedule are Straight Time.

reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental structure of the 4x10 compressed work week schedule, establishing the straight time days and hours. It's classified as 'schedule_definition' because it sets the baseline for all other rules applicable to this schedule.

name: CWW 4x10 Mon-Thu Friday Work at OT
rule_text: On a four (4) ten (10) schedule, when Friday is worked, the first ten hours shall be paid at one and oneha1f (1½x) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: When working on a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on the scheduled day off (Friday) are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> ASSIGN(OT, UP_TO(10))

expected_outcome.condition: The first 10 hours worked on a Friday under a 4x10 Mon-Thu schedule.

reasoning: This rule is classified as 'day_based' because it provides a specific pay rate for an entire day (Friday) when certain schedule conditions are met. It doesn't depend on exceeding a daily or weekly threshold, but rather on the day itself being worked.

name: CWW Daily Overtime After 10 Hours (Mon-Thu)
rule_text: Where these options are worked, all hours in excess of ten (10) hours per day Monday through Thursday, shall be paid for at two (2x) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On a compressed work week schedule, all hours worked beyond 10 in a day from Monday to Thursday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10_mon_thu', '10on_4off (llm)'] AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND is_scheduled_work_day == true -> THRESHOLD(ST, 10) AND ASSIGN(DT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after the 10th hour on a scheduled CWW day (Mon-Thu).

reasoning: This is a classic 'threshold_based' rule. It sets a clear numerical limit (10 hours) after which a different pay rate (double time) applies. It directly defines the transition from straight time to double time on a daily basis for compressed schedules.

name: CWW General Weekly Overtime
rule_text: In the case of a compressed work week, overtime premiums will be paid for hours worked in excess of ten in a day or forty in a week.
summary: On a compressed work week schedule, overtime premiums are paid for any hours worked beyond 40 in a week, provided they have not already been paid as daily overtime.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10_mon_thu', '10on_4off (llm)'] AND weekly_hours > 40 -> TRANSITION(OT)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after the 40th hour in a week on a CWW schedule, that are not already paid at a premium rate.

reasoning: This is classified as a 'threshold_based' rule because it establishes a weekly hour limit (40 hours) that triggers overtime. It complements the daily overtime rules by providing a weekly backstop for overtime calculation.

name: CWW OT Override for Commercial/Institutional Projects
rule_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, all overtime hours on Commercial/Institutional projects shall be paid for at the rate of time and one-half
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects, all overtime hours under the compressed work week schedule are paid at time and a half, which overrides the standard double time rule for hours over 10 per day.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] -> OVERRIDE('CWW Daily Overtime After 10 Hours (Mon-Thu)') AND THRESHOLD(ST, 10) AND ASSIGN(OT, AFTER(10))

expected_outcome.condition: Daily hours over 10 on a CWW for a Commercial or Institutional project.

reasoning: This rule is classified as 'exception_override' because of the explicit 'Notwithstanding the foregoing' language. It changes the pay rate of a previously defined rule ('CWW Daily Overtime After 10 Hours') under a specific condition (project_type).

name: CWW OT Override for Local 488 Jurisdiction
rule_text: except for work in Local 488's jurisdiction where work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays shall be paid at double time.
summary: As an exception for Commercial/Institutional projects, work performed on Sundays and Statutory Holidays within Local 488's jurisdiction is paid at double time, overriding the time-and-a-half rule.
depends_on: CWW OT Override for Commercial/Institutional Projects
overrides: CWW OT Override for Commercial/Institutional Projects
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'Local 488 jurisdiction' AND (day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> OVERRIDE('CWW OT Override for Commercial/Institutional Projects') AND ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a Sunday or Stat Holiday in Local 488's jurisdiction on a Commercial/Institutional project.

reasoning: This is a nested 'exception_override'. It uses the word 'except' to modify the rule immediately preceding it. It applies only under very specific conditions (location, day type, project type) and changes the pay calculation from that parent rule.

name: CWW 10on/4off Schedule Definition
rule_text: A ten (10) on and four (4) off schedule may also be established as a compressed work week schedule and when utilized, the straight time days will be Tuesday through Friday in one week followed by Monday through Thursday in the subsequent week.
summary: Defines a '10 on and 4 off' schedule where straight-time days are Tuesday-Friday in the first week and Monday-Thursday in the second week of the rotation.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10on_4off (llm)' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 -> DEFINE_SCHEDULE(days=['TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'], daily_hours=10) AND IF schedule_type == '10on_4off (llm)' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 -> DEFINE_SCHEDULE(days=['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'], daily_hours=10)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked on Tue-Fri of week 1, and Mon-Thu of week 2 on a 10/4 schedule.

reasoning: This is classified as a 'schedule_definition' as it outlines the specific days and hours that constitute the normal work period for the '10 on/4 off' schedule, which is a non-standard, multi-week rotation.

name: CWW 10on/4off Scheduled Off-Days Pay
rule_text: Should an employee work on the scheduled days off, the Friday and Monday will be paid at time and one half (1½x), and the Saturday and Sunday will be paid at double time (2x).
summary: On a 10 on/4 off schedule, work on the scheduled off-days of Friday and Monday is paid at time and a half. Work on the scheduled off-days of Saturday and Sunday is paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10on_4off (llm)' AND is_scheduled_work_day == false AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'FRI'] -> ASSIGN(OT, ALL) ELSE IF schedule_type == '10on_4off (llm)' AND is_scheduled_work_day == false AND day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] -> ASSIGN(DT, ALL)

expected_outcome.condition: All hours worked on a scheduled day off during a 10/4 schedule, with the rate determined by the specific day.

reasoning: This rule is 'day_based' because the pay rate for work on scheduled off-days is determined entirely by which day of the week it is (Friday/Monday vs. Saturday/Sunday), not by the number of hours worked.

name: Standard Daily Overtime After 8 Hours
rule_text: Overtime premiums as specified in this Collective Agreement will be paid for all hours worked in excess of eight hours in a day.
summary: For standard (non-compressed) work schedules, overtime is paid for any hours worked beyond eight in a single day.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 8 -> TRANSITION(OT)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours worked after the 8th hour on a standard workday.

reasoning: This is a fundamental 'threshold_based' rule for standard workdays. The text mentions it in contrast to the compressed work week rule, implying it's the default. It establishes the 8-hour daily limit before overtime begins.

name: Overtime Qualification with Pre-authorized Absence
rule_text: A worker who is preauthorized to take personal time off pursuant to the above procedure, will qualify for overtime premiums for any work performed either preceding or following the normal scheduled hours of work on the day they take their personal absence regardless of whether or not they have worked the full eight or ten hours as scheduled for that shift.
summary: A worker with a pre-authorized absence is still eligible for daily overtime pay (e.g., after 8 or 10 hours of total elapsed time in the workday), even if they haven't personally worked the full straight-time portion of the shift.
depends_on: Overtime Disqualification for Unexcused Absence (Make-up Time)
overrides: Overtime Disqualification for Unexcused Absence (Make-up Time)
logical_representation: IF is_preauthorized_absence (llm) == true -> OVERRIDE('Overtime Disqualification for Unexcused Absence (Make-up Time)') AND APPLY_NORMAL_OT_THRESHOLDS

expected_outcome.condition: Overtime is paid based on the shift's scheduled hours, not hours worked, if the absence was pre-authorized.

reasoning: This rule is an 'exception_override' because it explicitly negates the standard requirement to work a full shift before earning overtime. It creates a special case based on the condition of having a pre-authorized absence.

name: Overtime Disqualification for Unexcused Absence (Make-up Time)
rule_text: Workers who are absent from work without pre-authorization, must work the minimum normal hours as stipulated above prior to overtime premiums being paid. ... If scheduled straight time hours are missed due to unexcused absences the worker must work their straight time hours scheduled before overtime hours are earned.
summary: A worker with an unexcused absence (including late arrivals or early quits) must first work their full number of scheduled straight-time hours (e.g., 8 or 10) before becoming eligible for any overtime pay.
logical_representation: IF is_unexcused_absence (llm) == true -> REQUIRE(worked_daily_st_hours (llm) >= scheduled_daily_hours (llm)) AND REQUIRE(worked_weekly_st_hours (llm) >= scheduled_weekly_hours (llm)) BEFORE TRANSITION(OT)

expected_outcome.condition: Hours that would normally be overtime are paid as straight time until the missed hours from an unexcused absence are made up.

reasoning: This is a 'condition_based' rule because it imposes a prerequisite (making up missed time) that must be met before normal overtime rules can apply. The trigger is the status of the absence ('unexcused').

name: Pre-authorized Leave Request Conditions
rule_text: An employee who has not been absent, including late arrivals or early quits, or granted leave in the previous calendar 30 days, and who gives the Employer at least three working days' notice of a request for leave of up to one day, will be granted the requested leave.
summary: Defines the conditions for an absence to be considered 'pre-authorized': no unexcused absences or leaves in the prior 30 calendar days, and at least three working days' notice given to the employer for the request.
logical_representation: IF prior_30_day_attendance_perfect (llm) == true AND leave_request_notice_days (llm) >= 3 -> SET is_preauthorized_absence (llm) = true

expected_outcome.condition: Determines if an employee's request for time off meets the criteria to be considered 'pre-authorized'.

reasoning: This rule is 'condition_based' and doesn't directly assign pay. Instead, it defines the state of a crucial variable ('is_preauthorized_absence') that other pay-related rules depend on. It's a foundational rule for determining the outcome of absence-related pay calculations.

name: Call Out Minimum Pay - No Work Commenced
rule_text: Employees who do not commence work shall be paid for two (2) hours at the applicable overtime rate, and any travel and transportation applicable.
summary: An employee called out after their shift who goes to the site but does not start work is guaranteed a minimum of 2 hours of pay at the overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'EMERGENCY_CALLOUT' AND call_out_work_commenced (llm) == false -> VALIDATE(MINIMUM(OT, 2))

expected_outcome.condition: A minimum of 2 hours must be paid for a call out where work was not commenced.
